01_0003.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE INDICATION: recent covid, sob, elevated dimer, eval pe Was there a contrast reaction? No Was there a contrast or saline extravasation? No COMPARISON: Radiograph 2/10/2024, CT chest 8/9/2023. TECHNIQUE: Contrast enhanced chest CT performed during the injection of 80 ml of Isovue 370. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions and multiplanar reformats were performed. FINDINGS: CTA findings: No acute pulmonary embolism to the segmental level. Main pulmonary artery is dilated measuring 3.3 cm.. No interventricular septal bowing to suggest acute right heart strain. Thyroid: Heterogenous enlarged thyroid with bilateral thyroid nodules, the largest of which is in the right thyroid lobe measuring up to 3.0 cm (series 5, image 41). This is unchanged in size compared to 8/9/2023. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular adenopathy. Heart and great vessels: Heart is normal in size. Extensive three-vessel coronary calcifications and/or stents. No pericardial effusion. Mildly ectatic ascending thoracic aorta measuring 4.0 cm in diameter. Severe calcified atherosclerosis of the aortic arch and proximal great vessels. Mediastinum and hila: Evaluation of mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy is somewhat limited by contrast phase and streak artifact. Interval enlargement of a pathologically enlarged right cardiophrenic lymph node measuring 2.2 x 2.9 cm, previously 1.9 x 2.4 cm (series 5, image 281). Small hiatal hernia. Airway, lungs, and pleura: Central airways are patent. Diffuse bronchial wall thickening. Interval enlargement in number of innumerable pulmonary metastases, multiple which are cavitary. Multiple new pulmonary nodules. * Dominant cavitary lesion in the left upper lobe now measures 3.0 x 2.6 cm (series 5, image 117), previously 1.9 x 1.8 cm. * Dominant mass in the right lower lobe measures 4.1 x 4.0 cm (series 5, image 204), previously 3.2 x 3.1 cm. Small right pleural effusion. Chest wall and axilla: Diffuse soft tissue anasarca. Symmetric gynecomastia. Bones and soft tissues: Diffuse bone demineralization. L1 hemangioma. Multilevel thoracic spondylosis. Exaggerated kyphosis. Upper abdomen: Extensive circumferential visceral arterial calcifications. Increased size of partially imaged mass is between the superior right kidney and liver measuring 2.6 and 2.0 cm in disease series 5, image 3051). IMPRESSION: 1. No acute pulmonary embolism to the segmental level. 2. Compared to 8/9/2023, interval progression of metastatic disease throughout the lungs, chest, and upper abdomen as described above. 3. Stable enlarged thyroid gland with multiple hypoattenuating nodules. Ultrasound evaluation is advised if not already performed. I have personally reviewed the images and agree with the resident preliminary report. Preliminary Interpretation by: Robert Meller, MD at 2/10/2024 4:02 PM Final Report E-Signed By: JENNIFER KWAK, MD at 2/10/2024 4:46 PM WSN:PACSR70648

01_0004.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE DATE OF EXAM: 02/18/2024, 1506 INDICATION: . Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, high prob Was there a contrast reaction? No Was there a contrast or saline extravasation? No TECHNIQUE: Using multidetector CT, contrast enhanced chest CT was performed with contrast in pulmonary arterial phase. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. Three-dimensional coronal and sagittal MIP reconstructions were performed. CONTRAST: Isovue 370 65 mL COMPARISON: Chest radiograph 2/18/2024, CT abdomen pelvis 4/26/2017 FINDINGS: CTA: Contrast bolus timing allows for adequate evaluation to the level of the subsegmental pulmonary arteries. No filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolus. No findings to suggest right heart strain. Thyroid: Suboptimally evaluated left thyroid nodule measuring approximately 1.7 x 1.7 cm. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: Mildly prominent bilateral hilar/perihilar lymph nodes and up to 1.2 cm short axis. The thoracic esophagus is unremarkable. Heart and great vessels: Normal size of the heart. No significant pericardial effusion. Normal caliber main pulmonary artery. No thoracic aortic aneurysm. Lungs, airway and pleura: Right greater than left peribronchial and peripheral scattered groundglass and nodular opacities and mild diffuse right greater than left bronchial wall thickening. Scattered subcentimeter nodules bilaterally, for example a 5 mm nodule in the anterior right upper lobe (6/123) and a 5 mm nodule in the lateral left upper lobe (6/117). No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Central airways are clear. Chest wall and axilla: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable. Bones and Soft Tissues: Mild multilevel degenerative changes of the spine. Prominent flowing anterior osteophytes/syndesmophytes. No aggressive osseous lesion. Superficial soft tissues are within normal limits. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism to the levels of subsegmental pulmonary arteries. 2. Right greater than left peribronchial and peripheral scattered patchy groundglass and nodular opacities, and mild perihilar right greater than left bronchial thickening, consistent with a multifocal infectious/inflammatory process. Scattered subcentimeter nodules bilaterally, likely also infectious/inflammatory. Recommend follow-up with outpatient CT chest in 3-6 months after resolution of acute presentation. 3. Mildly prominent bilateral hilar lymph nodes. 4. Suboptimally evaluated left thyroid nodule measuring approximately 1.7 cm. Recommend nonemergent outpatient evaluation with thyroid ultrasound. Attending review: I have reviewed the resident preliminary report and agree with the findings. CONTACT INFORMATION: This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. If there are any questions regarding this report or other radiology questions, please feel free to contact a radiologist directly at 720-848-RADS (7237) or if in the UCH hospital or clinics at 8-RADS. 01_0014.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE DATE OF EXAM: 02/07/2024, 1448. INDICATION: Bilateral knee arthroscopic surgery 02/06/2024. Shortness of breath. Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, positive D-dimer. COMPARISON: CT chest abdomen pelvis 10/20/2023. TECHNIQUE: CT angiography of the chest was performed with contrast bolus timing allowing for adequate evaluation to the level of segmental pulmonary arteries using 70 mL of Isovue 370. Post-processing included the production of axial, coronal and sagittal multiplanar reformatted images and axial and coronal maximum intensity projections (MIPs). FINDINGS: Thyroid: Unremarkable thyroid gland. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.. Mediastinum and hila: No mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy.. The thoracic esophagus is unremarkable.. Heart and great vessels: . Enlarged main pulmonary artery with greatest transverse diameter of 3.4 cm. No filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolism to the proximal subsegmental level. Enlarged right heart chambers. Left anterior descending artery stent. Mild coronary calcifications in the circumflex and right coronary artery. Moderate mitral annular calcifications. No significant pericardial effusion. Borderline ectatic ascending aorta, measuring up to 3.6 cm. Lungs, airway and pleura: The central airways are patent. Mild proximal bronchial wall thickening. Interval increase in interlobular septal thickening and mosaic attenuation with patchy groundglass opacities. Unchanged small to moderate bilateral pleural effusions with adjacent passive atelectasis. No suspicious pulmonary nodules. Breast and axilla: Breast fibroglandular tissue outside the field-of-view. No suspicious axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Contrast reflux into the IVC and hepatic veins. Unchanged punctate splenic calcifications. No hiatal hernia. Visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.. Bones and Soft Tissues: There is mild degenerative change of the lower thoracic spine. No aggressive osseous lesion. Chronic left sixth rib fracture. Diffuse subcutaneous fat stranding, likely in the setting of volume overload. IMPRESSION: 1. No acute pulmonary embolism. 2. Interval increase of interlobular septal thickening and patchy groundglass opacities, likely representing pulmonary edema. 3. Additional diffuse subcutaneous fat stranding, likely in the setting of volume overload. Unchanged small bilateral pleural effusions. 4. Right heart chamber enlargement associated with dilatation of the main pulmonary artery and contrast reflux into the inferior vena cava and hepatic veins, likely in the setting of pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. Query as clinically indicated. ------------------------------------------------------------------------ CONTACT INFORMATION: This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. 01_0042.answer: CTA chest for PE DATE OF EXAM: 2/6/2024 INDICATION: Pulmonary embolism suspected, high probability. TECHNIQUE: Using multidetector CT, contrast enhanced chest CT was performed with contrast in pulmonary arterial phase. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. Three-dimensional coronal and sagittal MIP reconstructions were performed. CONTRAST: Isovue 370 100 mL COMPARISON: CT PE 12/22/2023 FINDINGS: CTA: Contrast bolus timing allows for adequate evaluation to the level of the segmental pulmonary arteries. No filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolus. No findings to suggest right heart strain. Previously seen right lower lobe segmental pulmonary arterial emboli is no longer visualized. Thyroid: Visualized portions are normal. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: Unchanged prominent subcarinal lymph node measuring 1.4 cm (7/245). Left hilar lymph node measuring 1.6 cm, progressed from prior (6/148), likely reactive. Patulous esophagus dilated with fluid, with an enteric tube coursing into the gastric fundus. Heart and great vessels: Normal size of the heart. Trace pericardial fluid. Normal size of the great vessels. Lungs, airway and pleura: Similar narrowing of the intrathoracic trachea in anterior posterior dimension. Extensive debris is seen within the left greater than right main stem bronchi increased bilateral mucous plugging. There is near complete obliteration of the left lower lobe bronchi. Increased heterogenously enhancing consolidative opacity in the left lower lobe lung (6/158). Slightly increased right basilar consolidation/atelectasis. New irregular focal consolidation in the posterior superior segment of the left upper lobe lung (6/120). There is new extensive tree in bud nodularity throughout the left upper lobe lung and bilateral lower lobes. New nodule is seen within the left upper lobe lung on average measuring 0.6 cm (6/148). No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Breast and axilla: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable. Bones and Soft Tissues: There is mild degenerative change of the spine. Prominent anterior osteophytes in the lower cervical spine. No aggressive osseous lesion. Superficial soft tissues are within normal limits. IMPRESSION: 1. No central peripheral pulmonary embolus. 2. New extensive debris/secretions throughout the central airways with increased bibasilar mucous plugging and areas of consolidation concerning for aspiration pneumonia. 3. Extensive tree in bud nodularity is suggestive of aspiration. However, superimposed bronchiolitis is a differential consideration. Recommend attention follow up to confirm resolution. 4. Again seen small AP diameter of the intrathoracic trachea. Tracheomalacia is a differential consideration. Upon resolution of acute illness, follow-up CT chest with inspiratory and expiratory phases may be considered for further evaluation. CONTACT INFORMATION: This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. If there are any questions regarding this report or other radiology questions, please feel free to contact a radiologist directly at 720-848-RADS (7237) or if in the UCH hospital or clinics at 8-RADS. 01_0075.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE DATE OF EXAM: 2/7/2024 INDICATION: Pulmonary embolism suspected, high probability TECHNIQUE: Using multidetector CT, contrast enhanced chest CT was performed with contrast in pulmonary arterial phase. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. Three-dimensional coronal and sagittal MIP reconstructions were performed. CONTRAST: Isovue 370 50 mL COMPARISON: None FINDINGS: CTA: Contrast bolus timing allows for adequate evaluation to the level of the segmental pulmonary arteries. No filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolus. No findings to suggest right heart strain. Thyroid: Visualized portions are normal. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: No mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. The thoracic esophagus is unremarkable. Heart and great vessels: Four-chamber cardiac enlargement. There is some reflux of contrast into the IVC and hepatic veins. No significant pericardial effusion. Normal size of the great vessels. Lungs, airway and pleura: The central airways are patent. Mild peribronchial thickening. Multifocal centrilobular consolidative opacities and central portions of the right upper lobe lung (7/81). In the right lower lobe lung there is a nonenhancing consolidation (7/171). There is likely superimposed atelectasis at the lung bases. Additional nodular consolidative opacities in the left lower lobe lung, with one measuring 1.4 x 0.8 cm (7/127). No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Breast and axilla: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Borderline low attenuation throughout the hepatic parenchyma. Bones and Soft Tissues: There is mild degenerative change of the spine. No aggressive osseous lesion. Superficial soft tissues are within normal limits. IMPRESSION: 1. No central or peripheral pulmonary embolus. 2. Nonspecific new soft tissue thickening along the ascending aorta probably pericardial recess fluid, less likely intramural hematoma or inflammatory arteritis. If clinically warranted follow-up with dedicated CTA dissection protocol of the chest is suggested for further evaluation. 3. Multifocal central nodular opacities, with an area of consolidation in the left lower lobe lung is concerning for aspiration and/or multifocal pneumonia. Recommend attention on follow-up CT to confirm resolution. 4. Four-chamber cardiac enlargement with reflux of contrast into the hepatic veins may be seen with elevated right heart pressures in the right clinical setting. 5. Possible hepatic steatosis. Critical findings and impression points #s 1 and 2 were discussed with Brian Hughes MD of the MICU team at 11:14 AM to 7/20/2024, via phone by Dr. Parker Quimby. CONTACT INFORMATION: This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. If there are any questions regarding this report or other radiology questions, please feel free to contact a radiologist directly at 720-848-RADS (7237) or if in the UCH hospital or clinics at 8-RADS. Preliminary Interpretation by: Parker Quimby, MD at 2/7/2024 11:18 AM Final Report E-Signed By: Rocio Perez Johnston at 2/7/2024 11:30 AM WSN:PACSR64680

Mediastinum and hila: Since 1/11/2024, slightly increased size of multiple enlarged mediastinal and bilateral hilar lymph nodes. For reference, a prevascular node measures 3.0 x 1.7 cm, previously 2.6 x 1.4 mm, a bulky left hilar nodal conglomerate encasing the left central pulmonary vasculature measures the 3.6 x 3.5 cm, previously 3.3 x 3.1 cm, and a reference right hilar lymph node measures 13 mm short axis, previously 8 mm short axis (series 6 images 141, 170, 205). Normal caliber and patent thoracic aorta with mild arch atherosclerotic calcifications. Lungs, airway and pleura: Since 1/11/2024, new small left and trace right pleural effusions. Adjacent atelectasis. Slightly increased peribronchovascular nodular thickening in the left lower lobe (6/188) and inferior posterior left upper lobe (6/170). Unchanged perifissural nodule measuring 6 x 4mm along the inferior aspect of the right major fissure (6/172), however increased nodular thickening of the right major fissure superiorly, for example a more discrete nodular focus measuring 9 x 6mm along the superior aspect of the fissure (6/147). Focal small opacity with air bronchogram in the left lung lingula slightly increased from prior, favored to reflect atelectasis and/or sequela of aspiration. Breast and axilla: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Multiple arterially hyperenhancing hepatic masses newly conspicuous to prior 12/12/2023 and increased in size. For reference dominant right hepatic mass with peripheral hyperenhancement and central decreased enhancement measures 5.3 x 5.1 cm, previously 4.6 x 4.3 cm on 1/11/2024. Several hyperenhancing subcentimeter satellite nodules near this dominant mass are newly apparent compared to 12/12/2023, as well as several other newly apparent subcentimeter lesions scattered throughout the liver. Increased size of avidly enhancing right adrenal masses, the superior larger one measuring 2.0 x 1.7 cm, previously 1.4 x 1.3 cm. Slightly increased size of multiple upper abdominal soft tissue nodules/nodes, for reference a left paraaortic hyperenhancing soft tissue nodule measuring 2.4 x 1.4 cm, previously 2.0 x 1.0 cm (6/330) Slightly increased left upper abdominal peritoneal implant abutting the adjacent spleen measuring 1.1 x 0.7 cm, previously 0.9 x 0.6 cm (6/316). Newly apparent hyperenhancing soft tissue nodule in the left paravertebral soft tissues the level of the aortic hiatus measuring 1.0 x 0.6 cm (6/329). Left kidney surgically absent. Partially imaged right upper pole renal cyst. Bones and Soft Tissues: New sclerotic lesion in the posterior inferior right corner of the L2 vertebral body, suspicious for new osseous metastasis.. No acute fracture. Superficial soft tissues are within normal limits. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism to the level of subsegmental pulmonary arteries. 2. Overall increased metastatic disease in the chest and upper abdomen, including increased size of mediastinal, hilar, and upper abdominal lymphadenopathy, hepatic metastases, right adrenal masses, and perisplenic peritoneal implant. Several newly apparent hepatic masses compared to 12/12/2024. 3. Since 1/11/2024, increased left lower lobe and inferior left upper lobe peribronchovascular nodular thickening, and nodular thickening along the superior aspect of the right major fissure. In setting of metastatic disease, findings suspicious for lymphangitic carcinomatosis, versus infectious/inflammatory etiology. New small left and trace right pleural effusions. 4. New sclerotic lesion in the posterior inferior right corner of the L2 vertebral body, suspicious for new osseous metastasis. 5. Newly apparent hyperenhancing 1.0cm soft tissue nodule in the left paravertebral soft tissues the level of the aortic hiatus, also suspicious for metastatic disease. Mild bibasilar atelectasis and/or scarring. No dense consolidation. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. No suspicious nodules. Breast and axilla: Prominent but morphologically benign bilateral axillary lymph nodes, likely reactive. Dense bilateral breast tissue. Upper abdomen: Multiple radiopaque densities in the left upper quadrant which were observed on prior CT abdomen 2/20/2023. Advanced proximally visualized aortic atherosclerotic disease. Remote appearing left-sided rib fractures. No acute bony or soft tissue abnormality. IMPRESSION: 1. Normal evidence of acute pulmonary embolism. 2. Central and peripheral mucoid debris with distal airway impaction and multifocal tree-in-bud and groundglass opacities, suggesting bronchopneumonia, likely secondary to aspiration given patulous thick-walled upper esophagus. 3. Moderate to severe aortic atherosclerotic disease. 4. Remote appearing compression deformity T4 vertebral body with near complete height loss. CONTACT INFORMATION: This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. 01_0095.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE EXAMINATION: CTA of the chest with IV contrast History : Syncope TECHNIQUE: Pulmonary embolus protocol - Thin-slice axial imaging of the chest was performed during maximal pulmonary arterial opacification with intravenous nonionic iodinated contrast. 3D coronal slab MIPs and 2D reconstructions in the coronal and sagittal planes were performed to aid in pulmonary embolus detection. Representative images have been stored on PACS. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. Contrast: 100 cc of Isovue-370 COMPARISON STUDIES: 5/18/2023, CT scans dating back to 2021. FINDINGS: Please note that this exam is optimized for assessment of the pulmonary arteries and is not intended as a diagnostic study of the thoracic aorta, coronary arteries or venous structures. Angiographic Findings: Pulmonary arteries: There are no filling defects in the main, right, left, lobar, segmental or visualized sub-segmental branches of the pulmonary arterial system Other vasculature: Prominent calcification of the thoracic aorta and coronary vessels. The thoracic aorta is ectatic. Mid ascending thoracic aorta measures 3.3 cm. Distal aortic arch measures 3 cm. The upper abdominal aorta measures 3.2 cm.. Additional non-angiographic findings: Lungs / Pleura: Reidentified are numerous scattered pulmonary nodules many of which are cavitary. Biapical pleural scarring with some pleural calcification. When compared to recent prior CT 5/18/2023, the nodules are slightly enlarged some which are now cavitary. When compared to older CTs, these nodules have definitely progressed. Index nodules: 10 x 9 mm cavitary right upper lobe nodule (6/40), previously measured 11 x 7 mm 8 x 8mm cavitary right upper lobe nodule (6/113), previously measured 10 x 6 mm and was not cavitary. 19 x 8 mm cavitary right lower lobe nodule (6/191), previously measured 25 x 14 mm and was 2 discrete cavitary nodules. 9 x 9 mm cavitary left upper lobe nodule (6/175), previously measured 8 x 7 mm and was not cavitary. Mediastinum / Hila: negative. Heart / Pericardium: Atherosclerotic calcification. Lymph node assessment: negative Musculoskeletal / Body wall: Scoliosis with degenerative changes. Prior lumbar fusion Upper abdomen: Ectatic and mildly aneurysmal upper abdominal aorta measures 3.2 cm, stable IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence for pulmonary emboli the subsegmental level. 2. Scattered pulmonary nodules many of which are cavitary are slightly progressed when compared to CT 5/18/2023. The nodules have significantly progressed when compared to older CTs. Patient has seen pulmonary for evaluation of the nodules per EMR. Differential diagnosis includes infectious nodules (fungal/MAI) versus metastatic nodules. Further evaluation deferred to pulmonary. Final Report E-Signed By: Thomas Dunphy, MD at 2/23/2024 10:50 AM WSN:AMICRAD14

01_0103.answer: Procedure: CTA CHEST FOR PE - 02/14/2024, 0235. HISTORY: 65 years Female. Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, high prob Was there a contrast reaction? No Was there a contrast or saline extravasation? No. pt with recent trach; new vent requirement; rhonchi bilaterally IV contrast: 60 mL Isovue-370. Technique: Contiguous axial CTA images of the chest were performed after the administration of IV contrast. Post processed CTA MIP images of the pulmonary arteries were created and reviewed. The axial source images were also reviewed. IMMEDIATE ADVERSE EVENT: None Comparison: CTA chest dated 1/9/2024. Chest x-ray dated 1/13/2024. Findings: Redemonstrated tracheostomy cannula. Interval decrease in size of previously present small pericardial effusion. Mild to moderate coronary artery calcifications. The great vessels are unremarkable, with normal course and caliber. Borderline enlarged mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes, similar compared to prior. Soft tissue fullness in the left axilla with adjacent fat stranding, axial image 14 of series 5. The soft tissue lesion measures 2.7 x 2.8 cm similar to slightly decreased in size since prior study where it measured 2.9 x 3.0 cm. There are adjacent prominent left axillary lymph nodes, significantly decreased in size since prior study, which no longer meet size criteria for lymphadenopathy measuring up to 9 mm in short axis. Pulmonary artery caliber: 3.4 cm. No evidence of pulmonary emboli to the segmental levels. Bronchial wall thickening, more pronounced in the bilateral lower lobes. Multifocal lower lobe bronchial plugs, more pronounced in the right lower lobe. Interlobular septal thickening is noted along with groundglass opacities, most pronounced in the bilateral lower lobes, but also evident in the bilateral upper lobes. There is no pneumothorax. Trace right and small left pleural effusions. Visualized portions of the upper abdomen demonstrate splenomegaly. Small hiatal hernia. Chronic fracture of the sternum. Healing subacute fractures of the anterior right third through sixth ribs and anterior left second through seventh ribs. The collection of findings is likely related to prior resuscitation. IMPRESSION: No CT evidence of pulmonary emboli to the segmental levels. Bronchial wall thickening more pronounced in the bilateral lower lobes with multifocal lower lobe bronchial plugs, more pronounced on the right. Findings are consistent with airways disease. Interlobular septal thickening and groundglass opacities in both lungs, most pronounced in the bilateral lower lobes. Findings may represent pulmonary edema, improved since prior, or atypical infection. Improving bilateral pleural effusions, now trace right and small left. Interval decrease in size of previously present small pericardial effusion. Left axilla soft tissue mass and associated left axillary lymphadenopathy have decreased since prior study. The mass now measures 2.7 x 2.8 cm, previously 2.9 x 3.0 cm. It has increased in size since 4/11/2023 where it measured 1.5 x 2.0 cm. The mass is of unclear etiology, however given presence of splenomegaly a lymphoproliferative process cannot be excluded, other etiologies. Correlate with history. Consider biopsy, if clinically indicated. Healing subacute fractures of the sternum and bilateral ribs, likely related to prior resuscitation. TECHNIQUE: CT angiography of the chest with intravenous contrast. Sagittal, coronal and slab 3D MIP reconstructions. DOSE OPTIMIZATION: One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: 80 cc Isovue-370 IV contrast. No adverse contrast reaction reported. FINDINGS: LOWER NECK: Normal. HEART/PERICARDIUM: Normal heart size. AORTA/GREAT VESSELS: Minimal calcific atherosclerotic vascular disease. No thoracic aortic aneurysm or dissection. PULMONARY ARTERIES/PULMONARY ARTERIAL VASCULAR TREE: Dilated main pulmonary artery to 3.8 cm (previously 3.4 cm), consistent with pulmonary arterial hypertension. No pulmonary embolism. 3-D RECONSTRUCTED IMAGES: MIP images confirm and further demonstrate the findings from the axial source images. No additional focal abnormalities are seen. IVC/SVC: Normal. MEDIASTINUM: Unremarkable. LYMPH NODES: Index mediastinal lymph nodes as follows: * Stable 14 x 10 mm (#2:27) left paratracheal lymph node, previously 14 x 11 mm. * Stable 11 x 6 mm (#2:25) superior right paratracheal lymph node, previously 10 x 6 mm. * Involuting 12 x 11 mm (#2:28) right prevascular lymph node, previously 13 x 14 mm. * The previously demonstrated subcentimeter left supraclavicular lymph nodes are no longer identified either due to resolution or obscuration by artifact. THYROID: Thyroidectomy. Including 1.3 cm soft tissue fullness in the left thyroid bed, previously measuring 1.5 cm. Cannot exclude residual thyroid tissue. PLEURA/PLEURAL SPACES: Unremarkable. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. TRACHEA/BRONCHI: Normal trachea and bronchi. No narrowing of the cervical trachea. LUNGS: Innumerable 1-6 mm pulmonary nodules scattered throughout both lungs, increasing in number. Most of the nodules measure between 2 and 4 mm in size. No definite change in the size of the nodules since prior exam. Index lesions as follows: * Stable 6 mm right upper lobe pulmonary nodule (5:130). * Stable 3 mm lingular pulmonary nodule (5:280). CHEST WALL/SOFT TISSUES: Normal. UPPER ABDOMEN: Stable hepatic cyst. Stable subcentimeter splenic hypodensities, too small to characterize. Stable 2.2 cm benign left adrenal adenoma. BONES: No acute bony change. Stable heterogeneous marrow without discrete lytic or sclerotic lesion. SCOUT TOPOGRAM: Otherwise normal. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolism. 2. Prior thyroidectomy. Stable soft tissue fullness in the left thyroid bed. Cannot exclude residual thyroid tissue. 3. Innumerable pulmonary nodules, increasing in number but not size. Primary consideration is metastatic thyroid cancer. 4. Stable to involuting mediastinal lymph nodes. 5. Worsening pulmonary arterial hypertension. 6. Stable 2.2 cm benign left adrenal adenoma. 7. No narrowing of the cervical trachea. Final Report E-Signed By: David D Vaughn at 2/22/2024 10:02 PM WSN:AMICRAD71

Was there a contrast reaction? No Was there a contrast or saline extravasation? No . COMPARISON: CT PE 1/8/2024. TECHNIQUE: Contrast enhanced chest CT performed during the injection of 70 mL of Isovue-370 according to PE protocol. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. FINDINGS: CTA FINDINGS: Contrast bolus timing is adequate to rule out pulmonary embolus through the segmental pulmonary arteries. Main pulmonary artery is normal in caliber. No filling defects. OTHER FINDINGS: Thyroid: Mildly enlarged without discrete nodularity. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Heart and great vessels: Mild cardiomegaly. Atherosclerotic calcifications of the left anterior descending coronary artery. The thoracic aorta is normal in caliber. Mild atherosclerotic calcifications of the aorta and its branches. Mediastinum and hila: Calcified mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes, likely sequelae of prior granulomatous process. Stable mild mediastinal lymphadenopathy, minimally increased from prior study. For example, a precarinal node measures 1.0 cm. Similar patulous esophagus with mild wall thickening. Small hiatal hernia. Lungs, airways, and pleura: The central airways are patent. Mild bronchial wall thickening, again with scattered mucous impaction of the distal airways. Redemonstrated bilateral traction bronchiectasis, interlobular septal thickening, and reticulation within upper lobe predominance. Mildly increased geographic groundglass opacities. Unchanged 4 mm nodule in the left upper lobe (series 6/image 108). Scattered calcified granulomata. No pleural effusion. No pneumothorax. Chest wall and axillae: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Timing of contrast bolus limits evaluation of the upper abdominal solid organs and bowel. Splenic parenchymal calcified granulomas. Unchanged simple hepatic cysts and hepatic parenchymal calcified granulomas. Unchanged left adrenal nodule measuring 1.7 x 1.6 cm (series 8/image 139), unchanged dating back to at least 5/22/2022, and therefore likely benign. Bones: Diffusely demineralized bones. Mild thoracic levocurvature. Moderate degenerative changes of the spine. No acute osseous findings. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolus. 2. Mildly increased patchy bilateral groundglass pulmonary opacities, which may reflect atypical/viral infection versus exacerbation of known underlying interstitial lung disease. 3. Stable mild mediastinal lymphadenopathy. ________________________________________________ This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. 01_0193.answer: EXAMINATION: CTA CHEST FOR PE DATE: 02/16/2024, 2228 INDICATION: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected. Shortness of breath and hypoxia. Was there a contrast reaction? No Was there a contrast or saline extravasation? No . COMPARISON: Same day chest radiograph. TECHNIQUE: Contrast enhanced chest CT performed during the injection of 50 mL of Isovue-370 according to PE protocol. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. FINDINGS: CTA FINDINGS: Contrast bolus timing is adequate to rule out pulmonary embolus to the segmental pulmonary arteries. Dilated of the main pulmonary artery, measuring up to 4.0 cm in caliber No filling defects. OTHER FINDINGS: Thyroid: No nodularity. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Heart and great vessels: Borderline cardiomegaly. Ectasia of the ascending aorta, measuring up to 4.3 cm in caliber (measured on 902/150). Mediastinum and hila: Mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy, for example right pretracheal lymph node measuring 1.5 cm short axis (5/34). Enlarged right hilar lymph node measures 1.2 cm short axis (5/43). Enlarged infracarinal lymph nodes measuring up to 1.3 cm in maximal thickness. Patulous esophagus. Lungs, airways, and pleura: Suggestion of paraseptal emphysema. Secretions in the mid trachea (for example, as seen on series 6/image 84). Opacification of multiple distal airways bilaterally, with a dependent predominance. Diffuse bronchial wall thickening. Tree-in-bud nodularity in the peripheral right upper lobe 6/146). Small airspace opacity within the posterior right upper lobe, along the right major fissure (904/95) Faint groundglass opacities and questionable peribronchial vascular nodules in the bilateral lower lobes. Mild dependent atelectasis bilaterally. Pleural-based triangular pulmonary nodule in the anterior right upper lobe almost certainly reflects a pleural lymph node (6/139) or may represent sequela of infectious process. No pleural effusion. No pneumothorax. Chest wall and axillae: Mild right-sided gynecomastia. Upper abdomen: Timing of contrast bolus limits evaluation of the upper abdominal solid organs and bowel. Simple cyst in the right hepatic lobe. Partially visualized colonic diverticulosis. Bones and soft tissues: Moderate degenerative changes of the imaged spine. Sclerotic focus in the left lateral fourth rib (6/165) and lytic focus in the left lateral sixth rib (902/144). Diastasis recti. Mild right gynecomastia. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolus. 2. Diffuse bronchial wall thickening, secretions in the trachea, opacification of multiple bilateral distal airways, tree-in-bud nodularity in the peripheral right upper lobe along with associated consolidative airspace opacity. Findings concerning for aspiration pneumonia, airways disease or atypical infection. 3. Paraseptal emphysema with dilation of the main pulmonary artery, suggestive of chronic pulmonary arterial hypertension. 4. Ectasia of the ascending thoracic aorta measuring up to 4.3 cm in caliber. 5. Mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy, likely reactive. 6. Sclerotic focus in the left lateral fourth rib, favored to represent a bone island. 7. Nonspecific subcentimeter lytic focus in the left lateral sixth rib, indeterminate. Cannot exclude multiple myeloma or metastatic disease in the appropriate clinical setting. Correlate with prior imaging, if available, to assess for stability. Otherwise, attention on follow-up. ________________________________________________ This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. If there are any questions regarding this report or other radiology questions, please feel free to contact a radiologist directly at 720-848-RADS (7237) or if in the UCH hospital or clinics at 8-RADS. Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, high prob TECHNIQUE: Using multidetector CT, contrast enhanced chest CT was performed with contrast in pulmonary arterial phase. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. Three-dimensional coronal and sagittal MIP reconstructions were performed. CONTRAST: Isovue 370 50 mL COMPARISON: High-resolution chest CT from 2/5/2024 at national Jewish health. FINDINGS: Chest wall/mediastinum: Stable cardiomegaly. No pericardial effusion. Mild atherosclerotic thoracic aorta, normal caliber of the 3.5 cm. Adequate opacification of the pulmonary arterial tree without central filling defect to suggest acute pulmonary embolism. Main pulmonary artery normal in caliber measuring 2.7 cm. Left-sided PICC with tip at least within the proximal SVC. No mediastinal or hilar adenopathy. Right hilar/suprahilar soft tissue fullness consistent with postsurgical changes from recent right upper lobe anterior segmentectomy. Thyroid is unremarkable. No supraclavicular or other significant axillary adenopathy. Pleural/parenchyma: Scattered mucoid debris throughout the central airways. Again, postsurgical changes from recent right upper lobe anterior segmentectomy. Small loculated right anterior pneumothorax. Soft tissue fullness of the right hilar and suprahilar consistent with postsurgical changes. Mild diffuse bronchial wall thickening. Distal mucous plugging with associated nodular and linear consolidation in the posterior basilar left lower lobe suggestive of atelectasis. Additional atelectasis or scarring with distal bronchiectasis in the anterior lingula. Additional patchy basilar predominant subpleural nodular opacities, increased since prior. Small volume complex layering right effusion and suggestive of underlying small hemothorax, presumably postoperative. Multifocal groundglass and linear abnormality throughout the lungs, which may represent atypical infection, pulmonary edema or simply secondary to atelectasis superimposed on expiratory phase of imaging. No left-sided pneumothorax. Stable left apical nodular scarring with distal bronchiectasis. Visualized upper abdomen demonstrates no acute abnormality. No acute bony abnormality. No significant soft tissue abnormality. IMPRESSION: 1. Negative for acute pulmonary embolism. 2. Recent postsurgical changes from right upper lobe anterior segmentectomy. 3. Small right apical loculated pneumothorax. Small volume complex right pleural effusion, likely underlying blood products. 4. Multifocal groundglass and linear opacities throughout, either multifocal atelectasis, edema or atypical/viral pneumonia. 01_0220.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE HISTORY: 2 days of cough, congestion, shortness of breath, and chest pressure. Elevated d-dimer. COMPARISON: None. TECHNIQUE: Pulmonary embolus protocol: Thin-slice axial imaging of the chest was performed during maximal pulmonary arterial opacification with intravenous nonionic iodinated contrast. Sagittal and coronal reformats and axial, sagittal, and coronal MIP series were performed to aid in pulmonary embolus detection. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: 70 mL of IV Isovue-370. FINDINGS: PULMONARY ARTERIES: The pulmonary trunk is normal in caliber. Pulmonary arteries are adequately opacified to the suboptimal although adequate pulmonary artery opacification to the subsegmental level. Respiratory motion limits evaluation. No central pulmonary embolism. No segmental or subsegmental pulmonary embolism within the limits of the examination. THORACIC INLET: Normal. AORTA AND ARCH BRANCH VESSELS: No aneurysm or dissection. There is no atherosclerosis of the aorta. HEART/PERICARDIUM: The heart is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. There is no coronary artery calcification. MEDIASTINUM/HILA: Small mediastinal lymph nodes. Enlarged right hilar lymph node, which measures 1.1 cm in cross-section (image 60 series 2). LUNGS/PLEURA: No pleural effusion. Mild atelectasis. No pneumothorax. Bronchial thickening, greatest in the right lower lobe, where there is segmental bronchiole opacification. UPPER ABDOMEN: Liver measures less than 40 Hounsfield units, in keeping with hepatic steatosis. There is focal fatty sparing at the gallbladder fossa. Patent portal vein. Bilateral nonobstructing renal calculi. MUSCULOSKELETAL/VERTEBRA/BODY WALL: No acute abnormality. Tiny sclerotic lesion within the anterior T8 vertebra is most likely a benign bone island. IMPRESSION: 1. No central pulmonary embolism and no segmental or subsegmental pulmonary embolism within the limits of the examination. 2. Bronchial thickening, which may be due to bronchitis. 3. Enlarged right hilar lymph node is likely reactive. 4. Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver), which can lead to steatohepatitis and eventual cirrhosis. 5. Bilateral nonobstructing renal calculi. Final Report E-Signed By: Becky Benz, MD at 2/19/2024 2:17 AM WSN:M-RAD020

No Was there a contrast or saline extravasation? No TECHNIQUE: Using multidetector CT, contrast enhanced chest CT was performed with contrast in pulmonary arterial phase. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. Three-dimensional coronal and sagittal MIP reconstructions were performed. CONTRAST: Isovue 370 60 mL COMPARISON: None FINDINGS: CTA: Contrast bolus timing allows for adequate evaluation to the level of the segmental pulmonary arteries. No filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolus. No findings to suggest right heart strain. Thyroid: Visualized portions are normal. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: Prominent mediastinal lymph nodes without pathologic enlargement. No hilar adenopathy. The thoracic esophagus is unremarkable. Heart and great vessels: Four-chamber cardiac enlargement. Moderate-severe coronary artery calcifications and coronary stents. No significant pericardial effusion. Normal size of the great vessels. Moderate-severe atherosclerosis of the thoracic aorta. Lungs, airway and pleura: Retained secretions in the bilateral mainstem bronchi. Bronchial wall thickening and scattered mucous plugging. Scattered, but predominantly basilar reticular and ground glass opacities. A few areas of tree-in-bud nodularity. Lingular nodule (six, 159), measuring 0.4 cm and left upper lobe anterior subpleural nodule (six, 132), measuring 0.5 cm. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Breast and axilla: Mildly enlarged bilateral axillary lymph nodes with preserved fatty hilum and reniform shape. Upper abdomen: Fatty infiltration of the pancreas. Visualized portions of the upper abdomen are otherwise unremarkable. Bones and Soft Tissues: Sternotomy wires present. There is diffuse moderate degenerative change of the spine. No aggressive osseous lesion. Superficial soft tissues are within normal limits. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism to the level of the segmental arteries. 2. Bilateral bronchial wall thickening and bibasilar scattered mucous plugs probably inflammatory/aspiration. Bilateral groundglass opacities and mild bibasilar reticulation, possibly related to aspiration versus atypical infectious etiology. 3. Nonspecific left subcentimeter lung nodules. Follow-up is suggested. 4. Prominent mediastinal lymph nodes, likely reactive. 5. Cardiomegaly. 6. Coronary artery disease. CONTACT INFORMATION: This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. 01_0288.answer: EXAM DATE: 2/29/2024 2:26 AM PROCEDURES: CTA CHEST FOR PE CLINICAL DATA: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, positive D-dimer COMPARISON: CTA chest performed 2/16/2018 TECHNICAL DATA: Helical CT data through the chest after the uneventful intravenous administration of 75 ml of Isovue 370. Sagittal, and coronal reformats were created by the technologist. Post-processed, reconstructed multiplanar reformatted MIP images of the chest were also provided. All CT scans at this facility use dose modulation, iterative reconstruction, and/or weight based dosing when appropriate to reduce radiation dose to as low as reasonably achievable. FINDINGS: Mediastinum:Normal appearance of the thyroid. Multiple prominent and enlarged lymph nodes are seen throughout the mediastinum and bilateral hila. The largest mediastinal hilar lymph node measures up to 1.2 cm in short axis in the right hilum. Opacification of the pulmonary arteries is appropriate for evaluation of pulmonary embolus on this exam. No pulmonary arterial filling defects are seen to suggest pulmonary embolus. The pulmonary arteries and thoracic aorta are normal in course and caliber. Upper limits of normal cardiac size. Densely calcified atherosclerotic plaque deposition is seen in the distribution of the left main, LAD, circumflex and right coronary arteries. Normal appearance of the esophagus. Lungs and pleura: Trace bilateral pleural effusions. Paraseptal emphysematous changes are again seen throughout the lungs, most significant in the lung apices. No pneumothorax. Diffuse bronchial wall thickening is seen throughout the lungs, most significant in the perihilar regions and bilateral lower lobes. Redemonstration of a 0.6 cm noncalcified pulmonary nodule along the peripheral inferior lateral left lower lobe (image 3:15, series 3) which is similar in size and appearance compared with prior imaging dating back to 2/16/2018 allowing for differences in/selection and measurement technique between exams. There is also redemonstration of a 0.6 cm pleural-based nodule along the periphery of the right middle lobe (image 303, series 3) which is also stable compared with the 2/16/2018 exam. Mild pulmonary edema is seen in the mid and lower lungs. Normal appearance of the trachea and mainstem bronchi. Chest wall: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Subacute appearing single site fracture of the anterolateral right fourth rib with calcifying callus formation is seen surrounding fracture lines. Acute appearing single site fracture is seen at the anterolateral right third rib. Upper abdomen: Visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolus is seen. 2. Trace bilateral pleural effusions and mild pulmonary edema in the mid and lower lungs. 3. Diffuse bronchial wall thickening is seen throughout the lungs, most significant in the perihilar regions and bilateral lower lobes. Correlate for clinical signs or symptoms of bronchitis. 4. Coronary artery disease as above. 5. Acute appearing single site fracture is seen at the anterolateral right third rib. Subacute appearing single site fracture of the anterolateral right fourth rib with calcifying callus formation is seen surrounding fracture lines. 6. Redemonstration of a 0.6 cm noncalcified pulmonary nodule along the peripheral inferior lateral left lower lobe and a 0.6 cm pleural-based nodule along the periphery of the right middle lobe which are similar in size and appearance compared with prior imaging dating back to 2/16/2018 allowing for differences in/selection and measurement technique between exams. 7. Multiple prominent and enlarged lymph nodes are seen throughout the mediastinum and bilateral hila. The largest mediastinal hilar lymph node measures up to 1.2 cm in short axis in the right hilum. Report E-Signed By: Jason M Allen, DO at 2/29/2024 2:59 AM WSN:RICRADHOME11

Stable peripheral 5 mm pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe. New nodular opacities in the peripheral superior segment of the right lower lobe measuring up to 6-7 mm (series 6, image 114). Visualized upper abdomen: Negative. Bones/soft tissues: Chronic L1 endplate compression fracture. Multilevel degenerative disc disc disease. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolism. 2. New nodular opacity in the superior segment of the right lower lobe measuring up to 6-7 mm. Please see guidelines below. Recommend follow-up CT in 6-12 months. 3. Stable 5 mm pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe. 4. Findings of pulmonary arterial hypertension. 5. Mitral and aortic valve calcification. 6. Moderate size hiatal hernia. ---------- FLEISCHNER SOCIETY FOLLOW-UP GUIDELINES FOR NEWLY DETECTED INCIDENTAL NODULES IN PERSONS 35 YEARS OF AGE OR OLDER. *These recommendations do NOT apply to lung cancer screening, patients with immunosuppression or patients with a known primary malignancy. SOLITARY SOLID NODULE If nodule size is 8 mm: * Low risk patient ? Consider CT at 3, 9 and 24 months (if no change), PET/CT, tissue sampling or a combination thereof. * High risk patient ? Consider CT at 3, 9 and 24 months (if no change), PET/CT, tissue sampling, or a combination thereof. LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. HIGH RISK PATIENT: Tobacco use, family history of lung cancer, upper pulmonary lobe location of nodule, presence of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, older age. MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. Radiology. uchnipn Report E-Signed By: Douglas Watt at 2/27/2024 1:23 PM WSN:AMICRAD74

Upper Abdomen: Unremarkable. Chest Wall and Osseous Structures: Old healed bilateral rib fracture deformities. Moderate to marked degenerative changes of the spine. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism. 2. 1.2 cm right lower lobe pulmonary nodule. Additional semisolid/ground glass pulmonary nodule within the right middle lobe which measures up to 1.5 cm. Non-contrast chest CT at 3-6 months is recommended. If nodules persist, subsequent management will be based upon the most suspicious nodule(s) (Per Fleischner Society guidelines). ---------- FLEISCHNER SOCIETY FOLLOW-UP GUIDELINES FOR NEWLY DETECTED INCIDENTAL NODULES IN PERSONS 35 YEARS OF AGE OR OLDER. *These recommendations do NOT apply to lung cancer screening, patients with immunosuppression or patients with a known primary malignancy. MULTIPLE SOLID NODULES If nodule size is 8 mm: * Low risk patient ? CT at 3-6 months, then consider CT at 18-24 months if no change. * High risk patient ? CT at 3-6 months, then consider CT at 18-24 months if no change. LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. HIGH RISK PATIENT: Tobacco use, family history of lung cancer, upper pulmonary lobe location of nodule, presence of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, older age. MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. Radiology. Report E-Signed By: Aaron Frenette at 2/18/2024 7:06 PM WSN:M-RAD018

No filling defects in the lobar, segmental or subsegmental pulmonary arteries. Mild dilatation of the main arterial trunk at 2.8 cm. Multiple other superior mediastinal lymph nodes, mainly paraesophageal/peritracheal measuring up to 1.4 cm across the short axis.. Right hilar lymph node measuring up to 1.6 cm Chest Wall: Bilateral prominent in number axillary lymph nodes. There is an enlarged lymph node with apparent loss of fatty hilum seen inferior to the right subclavian vein measuring up to 1 cm. Thyroid: Unremarkable. Esophagus:No hiatal hernia. SOLITARY SUBSOLID NODULE GROUND GLASS: If nodule size is or equal to 6 mm: * CT at 6-12 months to confirm persistence, then CT every 2 years until 5 years if unchanged. PART SOLID: If nodule size is or equal to 6 mm with solid component or equal to 6 mm with solid component > or equal to 6 mm: * CT at 3-6 months to confirm persistence. If unchanged, should be considered highly suspicious. LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. HIGH RISK PATIENT: Tobacco use, family history of lung cancer, upper pulmonary lobe location of nodule, presence of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, older age. MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. FINDINGS: CTA CHEST: Please note that this exam is optimized for assessment of the pulmonary arteries and is not intended as a diagnostic study of the thoracic aorta, coronary arteries or venous structures. Angiographic Findings: Pulmonary arteries: Images are moderately degraded by respiratory motion artifact and suboptimal contrast bolus timing. Within these confines, there are no filling defects in the main, right, left, lobar or visualized segmental branches of the pulmonary arterial system. Other vasculature: Mild atherosclerotic calcification along the thoracic aorta without aneurysm. Additional non-angiographic findings: Lower neck: Negative. Lungs / Pleura: Solid pulmonary nodule in the left lower lobe measuring 5 mm (series 11, image 221). Smaller subpleural solid pulmonary nodule just superior and lateral to this in the left lower lobe measuring 2 mm (series 11, image 203). No airspace consolidation, pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Mediastinum / Hila: There are several mildly enlarged right hilar lymph nodes, for example a 1.0 cm lymph node in the inferior right hilum (series 5, image 52). A few borderline prominent left hilar lymph nodes and mediastinal lymph nodes. Heart / Pericardium: Cardiac size upper limits of normal. No pericardial effusion. Musculoskeletal / Body wall: Negative. Upper abdomen: Negative. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism to the segmental level. 2. No acute CT findings in the chest. 3. Mildly enlarged right hilar lymph nodes and borderline prominent mediastinal and left hilar lymph nodes. 4. Two solid pulmonary nodules in the left lower lobe, the larger of these measuring 5 mm. MULTIPLE SOLID NODULES If nodule size is 8 mm: * Low risk patient: CT at 3-6 months, then consider CT at 18-24 months if no change. * High risk patient: CT at 3-6 months, then consider CT at 18-24 months if no change. LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. HIGH RISK PATIENT: Tobacco use, family history of lung cancer, upper pulmonary lobe location of nodule, presence of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, older age. MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. 01_0496.answer: ADDENDUM: Peripheral groundglass opacities in the left upper lobe. Appearance is suggestive of underlying atypical infection. Underlying inflammatory process would have a similar appearance. Report E-Signed By: Alison Sheridan Nath at 2/8/2024 12:10 PM WSN:AMICRAD60 CT ABDOMEN/PELVIS WITH CONTRAST, CTA CHEST FOR PE HISTORY: Abdominal pain, acute, nonlocalized Abdominal pain, acute, nonlocalized TECHNIQUE: CT chest, abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. 3-D MIPS of the chest were performed on a nonindependent workstation. CONTRAST: 120 mL Isovue 370 COMPARISON: CT dated 8/21/2011 FINDINGS: CHEST: Devices: None. Thoracic inlet: Enlarged left supraclavicular nodes measuring up to 10 mm. Mediastinum and hila: Multiple enlarged cardiophrenic nodes measuring up to 32 x 32 mm. Multiple subcentimeter left hilar nodes and prevascular nodes. Left lower paratracheal node measuring 7 mm. Enlarged left paraesophageal node measuring 11 mm. Heart and great vessels: No pulmonary artery embolism. Are No pericardial effusion. The main pulmonary artery is normal in caliber. The ascending thoracic aorta is normal in caliber. Lungs, airway and pleura: There is a 5.2 x 1.6 cm are pleural-based nodules in the right lung base (image 35, series 7). Associated large pleural effusion. Peripheral patchy groundglass opacities in left upper lobe (image 195 series 7). Appearance is suggestive of underlying atypical infection. The right middle lobe and right lower lobe are partially collapsed. Extensive nodular thickening of the right hemidiaphragm (image 21, series 9). Soft tissue and Axilla: Subcentimeter left axillary nodes. Subtle nodular areas of increased attenuation of subcutaneous fat of the chest wall may reflect sequelae of prior trauma or inflammation. ABDOMEN/PELVIS: Liver: Multiple hypoattenuating masses in the right hepatic lobe with a dominant mass measuring 9.1 x 8.0 cm. Patent portal vasculature. Bile ducts: Negative. Gallbladder: Negative. Pancreas: Negative. Spleen: Negative. Adrenals: Negative. Kidneys and Bladder: Negative. Reproductive organs: Negative. Gastrointestinal tract: Appendix is normal in caliber small amount gas in the lumen. Formed stool is seen in the right colon and transverse colon left colon and sigmoid are largely decompressed. No obvious colonic mass identified. Large hiatal hernia. Mesentery/Peritoneum: Small volume pelvic free fluid and nodular peritoneal thickening consistent with peritoneal carcinomatosis. Omental nodular disease consistent with omental caking (image 49, series 9). Right lower quadrant implant measuring 48 x 41 mm (image 110, series 9). Retroperitoneum: Enlarged aortocaval node the level of the SMA measuring 22 x 44 mm (image 42, series 9). Retrocaval node measuring 21 mm. Enhancing nodule along the left common iliac chain measuring 11 mm (image 87, series 9). No pelvic sidewall adenopathy. Vasculature: Negative. Bones and Soft Tissue: Small fat-containing left inguinal hernia with a 13 x 14 mm metastatic implant along the spermatic cord (image 142, series 9). Supraumbilical hernia with a metastatic implant measuring 28 x 32 mm (image 89, series 9). Left rectus abdominis implant measuring 15 x 25 mm (image 90, series 9). There is an indeterminant sclerotic focus in the T10 vertebral body (image 81, series 903). IMPRESSION: Findings of metastatic disease with a large malignant right pleural effusion, mediastinal and left supraclavicular adenopathy, nodular right diaphragmatic thickening, retroperitoneal adenopathy, peritoneal carcinomatosis, anterior abdominal wall soft tissue implants and multiple hypoattenuating hepatic masses. There is no clear primary identified on this study. Could consider primary hepatic malignancy such as cholangiocarcinoma although absence of associated biliary dilation would be atypical. Recommend oncologic referral and correlation with tissue sampling. Soft tissue implant involving the patient's supraumbilical hernia would likely be amenable to percutaneous biopsy. No pulmonary artery embolism. Large right malignant pleural effusion with associated near-complete collapse the right lower lobe and partial collapse the right middle lobe. Critical findings were communicated by myself Dr. Alison Sheridan with Delotta, MD at 11:44 am. Report E-Signed By: Alison Sheridan Nath at 2/8/2024 11:45 AM WSN:AMICRAD60

FLEISCHNER SOCIETY FOLLOW-UP GUIDELINES FOR NEWLY DETECTED INCIDENTAL NODULES IN PERSONS 35 YEARS OF AGE OR OLDER. *These recommendations do NOT apply to lung cancer screening, patients with immunosuppression or patients with a known primary malignancy. SOLITARY SOLID NODULE If nodule size is < 6 mm: LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. HIGH RISK PATIENT: Tobacco use, family history of lung cancer, upper pulmonary lobe location of nodule, presence of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, older age. MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. Radiology. Report E-Signed By: Karen Alderfer, MD at 2/8/2024 3:44 PM WSN:AMICRAD59

01_0513.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE EXAMINATION: CTA of the chest with IV contrast History : Pulmonary embolism, high probability, metastatic squamous cell carcinoma TECHNIQUE: Pulmonary embolus protocol - Thin-slice axial imaging of the chest was performed during maximal pulmonary arterial opacification with intravenous nonionic iodinated contrast. 3D coronal slab MIPs and 2D reconstructions in the coronal and sagittal planes were performed to aid in pulmonary embolus detection. Representative images have been stored on PACS. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. Contrast: 70 cc of Isovue-370 COMPARISON STUDIES: CT chest 1/15/2024 as well as priors. FINDINGS: Please note that this exam is optimized for assessment of the pulmonary arteries and is not intended as a diagnostic study of the thoracic aorta, coronary arteries or venous structures. Angiographic Findings: Pulmonary arteries: There are no filling defects in the main, right, left, lobar, segmental or visualized sub-segmental branches of the pulmonary arterial system Other vasculature: High-grade narrowing of the origin of the left subclavian artery due to noncalcified plaque. Calcified coronary atherosclerotic disease. Right-sided chemotherapy catheter has the tip in the right heart. Additional non-angiographic findings: Lungs / Pleura: Reidentified is extensive metastatic disease to the chest. The right-sided pleural effusion has resolved. Numerous pulmonary nodules and pleural nodules on the right are otherwise essentially stable. Patient may have pleural carcinomatosis on the right based on the pleural nodularity. Index right lower lobe nodule measures 29 x 17 mm (2/145), stable. Several pulmonary pleural nodules on the left. Index left lower lobe nodule has enlarged measures 19 x 16 mm (2/181), previously 15 x 12 mm. Mediastinum / Hila: Reidentified is metastatic right lower cervical and mediastinal adenopathy which encases the right main pulmonary artery and right hilar structures extends superiorly and right paratracheal space, similar prior. The right mainstem bronchus, bronchus to right upper lobe bronchus intermedius or encased but patent. Index precarinal lymph node mass measures 2.6 x 2 cm which is stable. Small bilateral level 4 cervical lymph nodes are also potentially metastatic. Index left level 4 lymph node measures 10 x 7 mm (2/27). Index right level 4 cervical lymph node measures 8 x 6 mm (2/24. There is also some posterior mediastinal adenopathy adjacent to the aorta measuring 7 mm (2/153). . Heart / Pericardium: Coronary atherosclerotic calcification. Right-sided chemotherapy catheter has the tip the right heart. Narrowing of the SVC better appreciated on prior CT. Lymph node assessment: Metastatic adenopathy described above Musculoskeletal / Body wall: Extensive osseous metastatic disease not grossly changed from prior exam Upper abdomen: Extensive hepatic metastatic disease will be described on CT of the abdomen. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence for pulmonary embolus subsegmental level. 2. Interval resolution of the small right pleural effusion. 3. Extensive metastatic disease not significantly changed from prior CT 1/15/2024. Mild enlargement of the left lower lobe nodule. Other index measurements given above. 4. Hepatic metastatic disease will be described on CT of the abdomen. Report E-Signed By: Thomas Dunphy, MD at 2/9/2024 2:49 PM WSN:AMICRAD14

01_0535.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE, CT ABDOMEN/PELVIS WITH CONTRAST Provided history: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, high prob, Hemoptysis, acute on chronic respiratory failure, COPD, sepsis, recent pneumonia Additional pertinent history: none CTA CHEST: TECHNIQUE: Pulmonary embolus protocol - Thin-slice axial imaging of the chest was performed during maximal pulmonary arterial opacification with intravenous nonionic iodinated contrast. 3D coronal slab MIPs and 2D reconstructions in the coronal and sagittal planes were performed to aid in pulmonary embolus detection. Representative images have been stored on PACS. EKG gating: no Contrast: 75 ml Isovue 370 One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. COMPARISON STUDIES: No relevant priors FINDINGS: Angiographic Findings: Pulmonary arteries: There are no filling defects in the main, right, left, lobar, segmental or visualized sub-segmental branches of the pulmonary arterial system Thoracic aorta: negative. Additional non-angiographic findings: Lungs / pleura / hila: There is no consolidation or effusion. Background patchy mosaic pattern of density throughout both lungs. A think the lower density areas are abnormal revealing emphysematous disease. Superimposed are multiple subpleural cysts primarily located in the right middle lobe and the medial left lower lobe. Largest one of the right 5.4 cm. A partially loculated cystic structure in the anterior left lung base measures 5.5 x 5.9 cm with a dependent fluid level, potentially infected or recently bleeding. Lower neck: negative Mediastinum: negative Heart / pericardium: negative Other Vessels: negative Body wall: negative Upper abdomen: negative Lymph nodes: negative Bones: negative CT ABDOMEN PELVIS: Technique: Spiral scan was obtained from the lower chest through the symphysis with intravenous contrast One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. FINDINGS: Liver/biliary: Negative Pancreas: Negative Spleen: Negative Adrenal glands: Negative Kidneys / ureters / bladder / retroperitoneum: Negative Pelvic genitourinary: Negative. Bowel / peritoneum / mesenteries: No obstruction or acute inflammatory disease. Normal appendix. Vessels: negative Lymph nodes: negative Body wall: Moderate sized fat-containing non-inflamed sub-umbilical hernia. No bowel herniation. Musculoskeletal: There is a circumscribed lobulated heavily rim calcified lesion of the left femoral neck and upper diaphysis extending from and ostium to the endosteum but without evidence of expansion. No periostitis or soft tissue component. Multifocal small cystic lesions noted in the left femoral head. IMPRESSION: CTA CHEST: 1. There is no CT evidence of acute pulmonary embolism. 2. Emphysematous disease with cystic changes as above. One of these cysts in the anterior left lower lobe demonstrating dependent fluid level suggests either hemorrhage or infection. Doubt neoplasm. CT ABDOMEN PELVIS: 1. No source of sepsis identified. 2. Normal appendix. 3. Left femoral lesion as above. This appears nonaggressive and is likely fibro-osseous in origin. Low-grade chondrosarcoma is possible but I think unlikely. I would suggest a baseline left hip radiograph with follow-up hip radiograph in 6 months to document stability. If the patient presents with any hip pain in the meantime, earlier follow-up warranted. Report E-Signed By: Richard Pacini, MD at 2/10/2024 4:48 PM WSN:DS7POUDRE

SOLITARY SOLID NODULE If nodule size is 8 mm: * Low risk patient - Consider CT at 3, 9 and 24 months (if no change), PET/CT, tissue sampling or a combination thereof. * High risk patient - Consider CT at 3, 9 and 24 months (if no change), PET/CT, tissue sampling, or a combination thereof. LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. HIGH RISK PATIENT: Tobacco use, family history of lung cancer, upper pulmonary lobe location of nodule, presence of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, older age. MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. Representative images have been stored on PACS. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: 56 mL of IV Isovue-370. COMPARISON: Chest radiograph 2/14/2024, CT chest 9/16/2021 FINDINGS: CTA CHEST: Please note that this exam is optimized for assessment of the pulmonary arteries and is not intended as a diagnostic study of the thoracic aorta, coronary arteries or venous structures. Angiographic Findings: Pulmonary arteries: There are no filling defects in the main, right, left, lobar, segmental or visualized sub-segmental branches of the pulmonary arterial system. Other vasculature: Mild atherosclerotic plaque along the thoracic aorta without aneurysm. Additional non-angiographic findings: Lower neck: Diminutive or possibly surgically absent thyroid. Lungs / Pleura: Multifocal patchy and consolidative opacities scattered in the right lung which are new from prior. A few areas of hazy groundglass opacities scattered in the left lung. Small bilateral pleural effusions. Mild scattered interlobular septal thickening. Probable pleural parenchymal scarring in the lung apices. The central airways appear clear. . Mediastinum / Hila: Mildly enlarged mediastinal and right greater than left hilar lymph nodes may be reactive. Heart / Pericardium: Stable heart size. Annular calcifications of the mitral and aortic valves. No pericardial effusion. Conduction device in the right ventricle. Musculoskeletal / Body wall: Progression in height loss at the T8 vertebral body compression fracture when compared to the CT chest from 9/16/2021, now with severe height loss and worsening focal kyphosis. There is about 4 mm osseous retropulsion. Mild anterior wedging of the T9-T11 vertebral bodies unchanged. Upper abdomen: Moderate hiatal hernia. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism. 2. Multifocal groundglass and consolidative opacities in the right lung suspicious for multifocal pneumonia and/or aspiration. Milder scattered hazy groundglass opacities in the left lung. 3. Small bilateral pleural effusions. 4. Worsening height loss at the chronic T8 compression fracture since the CT chest from 9/16/2021, with now severe height loss. Osseous retropulsion measures about 4 mm. Report E-Signed By: Bryce Meyer at 2/16/2024 8:10 AM WSN:M-RAD020

01_0598.answer: EXAM: CTA CHEST FOR PE DATE: 2/14/2024 4:53 PM TECHNICAL DATA: CT of chest post IV nonionic contrast infusion was performed. MIP reconstructions were performed. All CT scans at this facility use dose modulation, iterative reconstruction, and/or weight based dosing when appropriate to reduce radiation dose to as low as reasonably achievable. CLINICAL HISTORY: Suspicion for PE COMPARISONS: 8/11/2021 FINDINGS: Pulmonary arteries: No filling defects in the main, left or right pulmonary arteries. No filling defects in the lobar, segmental or subsegmental pulmonary arteries. The main pulmonary trunk is dilated to 3.4 cm. Lungs: There are postoperative changes present involving the right upper lobe with residual subpleural thickening laterally. Within the right lower lobe, there are tree-in-bud-like branching opacities redemonstrated which are not significantly changed since prior. Additionally, there is no significant change in fibrotic appearance of the right lower anterior lobe.. There are a few fine reticular subpleural interstitial opacities left lower lobe which are increased from prior. Additional left lower lobe anterior scarring is present. There is diffuse bronchiolar, which is new since prior. Wall thickening. Previously identified right lobe intrapulmonary opacity is redemonstrated image 67 of series 905, and lies at the fissural reflection just lateral to the postoperative scar. This measures 1.2 x 0.8 cm compared to 1.18 by 0.78 cm previously and has the appearance of a perifissural lymph node and is unchanged overall. There is mosaic pattern of attenuation of the bilateral lungs, new from prior. Pleura: No effusion. Heart: Mild cardiomegaly. Severe atherosclerotic disease of the coronary vessels. Aorta: Scattered mild atherosclerotic disease, mostly within the origins of the three-vessel takeoff. Mediastinum: Redemonstration of multistation mediastinal prominent in number and appearance lymph nodes. These are overall unchanged in size and appearance. However there is increase in size of the superior paratracheal lymph node, now measuring 9 mm across that short axis on image 66 of series 5, previously 5 mm across that short axis. Chest Wall: Degenerative disease of the visualized spine and shoulder. No axillary lymphadenopathy. Thyroid: Unremarkable. Esophagus:No hiatal hernia Upper Abdomen: Liver size and attenuation is normal. New right hepatic 1.6 cm hypoattenuating ill-defined lesion due to grainy appearance of the liver. Spleen size and attenuation is normal. There are layering gallstones present. The adrenal glands are normal. The kidneys demonstrate cortical thinning. The visualized pancreas is normal. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolus demonstrated. 2. New diffuse thickening of the bronchioli/peribronchial cuffing as well as mosaic pattern of attenuation of the lungs, with differential diagnoses including early pulmonary edema versus bronchiolitis. 3. The main pulmonary trunk is dilated to 3.4 cm, which can be seen in pulmonary arterial hypertension. 4. Right chamber predominance cardiomegaly, likely related to above 5. New linear opacities within the left anterior lower lung lobe which can be related to scarring versus subsegmental atelectasis versus infectious process. Attention on follow-up is recommended. 6. Increase in size of superior right paratracheal lymph node from 4 to 9 mm. The remainder of the mediastinal lymph nodes are not significantly changed in size. Attention on follow-up is recommended. 7. New right hepatic 1.6 cm hypoattenuating ill-defined lesion . This can be a cyst. Correlation with ultrasound may be warranted. 8. Redemonstration of cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis. Report E-Signed By: Adam Khalil at 2/14/2024 6:44 PM WSN:MHC1PACSDR04

No evidence of pulmonary embolism or other acute abnormality. . MIPS quality measure - if the patient is a suitable candidate, consider evaluation for entry into a low-dose lung cancer screening protocol. Fleischner Society 2017 Guidelines for Management of Incidentally Detected Pulmonary Nodules in Adults SOLID NODULES* Less than 6mm (250 mm3) Single nodule Consider CT, PET/CT, or tissue sampling at 3 months Consider CT, PET/CT, or tissue sampling at 3 months Multiple nodules Low risk - CT at 3 - 6 months, then consider CT at 18-24 months High risk - CT at 3 - 6 months, then CT at 18 - 24 months Use most suspicious nodule as guide to management. Follow-up intervals may vary according to size. SUBSOLID NODULES* Single - Ground Glass Less than 6 mm ( 100 mm3) CT at 6 - 12 months to confirm persistent, then CT every 2 years until 5 years IF certain suspicious nodules 100 mm3) CT at 3 - 6 months to confirm persistence. If unchanged and solid component remains = 6mm, and nodules = 6 mm should be considered highly suspicious Multiple Less than 6 mm ( 100 mm3) CT at 3 - 6 months. Subsequent management based on the most suspicious nodule(s). Multiple < 6 mm pure ground-glass nodules are usually benign, but consider follow-up in selected patients at high risk at 2 and 4 years *dimensions are average of long and short axes, rounded to the nearest mm RISK FACTORS \T\ ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS: Nodule location Lung cancers occur more frequently in the upper lobes, with a predilection for the right lung Adenocarcinomas and metastases tend to be located in the periphery Squamous cancers are more often found near the hila Small solid nodules in a perifissural or subpleaural location often represent intrapulmonary lymph nodes Nodule multiplicity Total nodule count of 1 to 4 a increased risk of primary cancer Total nodule count of 5 or more nodules a decreased risk of cancer, more likely prior granulomatous disease Nodule growth rate Volume doubling times for solid cancers in the range of 100 to 400 days Volume doubling times for subsolid cancerous nodules more indolent, on the order of 3 - 5 years Emphysema and fibrosis Emphysema is an independent risk factor for lung cancer Pulmonary fibrosis is also an independent risk factor Age, sex, family history Risk increases with advancing age Female sex (overall odds ratio of 1.8) Tobacco Major risk factor for smoking 10 to 35 fold increased risk compared to nonsmokers Second hand smoke exposure also proven, albeit lesser, risk factor Smoking history of 30 pack years or more and quitting smoking within past 15 years is the qualifying tobacco threshold for NLST screening program Incidentally detected lung nodules on incomplete thoracic CT scans Small nodules < 6 mm No further investigation recommended Intermediate nodules 6 - 8 mm Follow-up CT of the complete chest after an appropriate interval (3 -12 months depending on clinical risk) Large or very suspicious nodule Proceed with complete thoracic CT exam for further evaluation Macmahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM et-al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. Radiology. 2017. volume pending. radiology.rsna.org Report E-Signed By: Chelsea Neesham at 2/14/2024 7:24 PM WSN:RICRAD35
