01_0671.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE HISTORY: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, high prob TECHNIQUE: CTA chest with intravenous contrast attention to pulmonary arteries. Sagittal, coronal and slab 3D MIP coronal reconstructed images were also created for further evaluation and interpretation. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: 62 mL of Isovue-370. COMPARISON: 10/23/2023 FINDINGS: Heart/vessels: Cardiomegaly. 3.5 cm abnormal dilatation of the right main pulmonary artery. This suggest pulmonary hypertension. No evidence of pulmonary emboli. Mild to moderate calcified plaque within the pulmonary arteries. Normal caliber aorta with mild atherosclerotic changes along its walls. Mediastinum: Negative. Lymph nodes: Negative. Lungs/pleura: Few groundglass opacities within the left upper lobe. Mosaic attenuation scattered within the lungs. Parenchymal bands within the lingula and both lower lobes consistent with atelectasis and/or scarring. 1.0 x 1.0 cm solid nodule abutting the pleura within the right lower lobe (6/198. No significant change since 2/7/2023. This may represent a pleural plaque. Attention on follow-up is recommended. Visualized upper abdomen: Cholecystectomy. Bones/soft tissues: Age appropriate spondylosis and hyperkyphosis. Postsurgical changes within the right humeral head. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary emboli. 2. Few groundglass opacities within the left upper lobe. This may represent a mild infectious or inflammatory process. 3. Mosaic attenuation within the lungs suggesting small airway disease. 4. Stable pleural-based nodule within the right lower lobe. Attention on follow-up is recommended. 5. Other chronic and incidental findings noted above. The results of this study were discussed with Dr. Mark Landmeier at 9:41 AM. Report E-Signed By: Andrea E Lyons, MD at 2/27/2024 9:44 AM WSN:M-RAD020

Sagittal, coronal and slab 3D MIP coronal reconstructed images were also created for further evaluation and interpretation. CONTRAST: Isovue-370 62 mls. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. COMPARISON: Chest x-ray November 21, 2023. Chest CT October 5, 2023 and November 17, 2023. Thyroid ultrasound October 30, 2023. FINDINGS: Neck: There is a right internal jugular vein chest port. There is a 3 cm nodule in the right lobe of the thyroid gland. There is another hypodense area that measures at least 2 cm. These nodules are better seen on previous ultrasounds. There is no retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy. Heart/coronary vessels: Negative. Pulmonary arteries: No filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolus. Thoracic aorta: Unremarkable without findings of dissection. Mediastinum: Negative. Lymph nodes: No axillary lymph nodes. Lungs/pleura: In the lung fields there are areas of focal and confluent groundglass density bilaterally. The most prominent findings are in the right upper lobe but there are noted in virtually every lobe. The findings could represent drug reaction, pneumonitis, atypical pneumonia or allergic alveolitis. Note that the patient has had groundglass densities in the past and correlation past medical history may be of benefit. Visualized upper abdomen: Marked hepatic steatosis. The gallbladder surgically absent. Bones/soft tissues: No sclerotic or lytic lesions noted. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolus. 2. Focal areas of groundglass density throughout the lung fields as described above most prominent in the right upper lobe. Differential diagnosis would include drug reaction, pneumonitis, atypical pneumonia, allergic alveolitis, opportunistic infection, pulmonary edema, etc. The patient has had this in the past and correlation with past medical history be beneficial. 3. Thyroid nodule better seen on previous thyroid ultrasound. 4. Hepatic steatosis. Results were called to AARON TRAVIS AST, M.D. At 2/19/2024 2:37 PM. Report E-Signed By: Steven Peck, MD at 2/19/2024 2:37 PM WSN:AMICRAD17

01_0678.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE HISTORY: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, positive D-dimer TECHNIQUE: CTA chest with intravenous contrast attention to pulmonary arteries. Sagittal, coronal and slab 3D MIP coronal reconstructed images were also created for further evaluation and interpretation. CONTRAST: Isovue-370 75 mls. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. COMPARISON: CT scan March 20, 2023. FINDINGS: Neck: There is no supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Heart/coronary vessels: There is no cardiac enlargement. Pulmonary arteries: There is no filling defect in the pulmonary arteries to suggest pulmonary embolus. Thoracic aorta: Unremarkable without findings of dissection. Mediastinum: There is a small low-density lesion in the right lobe of the thyroid gland. There is a 2.8 x 1.1 cm lymph node in the subcarinal region. There is a smaller calcified lymph node in the subcarinal region. There are calcified lymph nodes in the left hila. Lymph nodes: There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. Lungs/pleura: There are are extensive findings of groundglass density involving a large portion of the right upper lobe and both lower lobes as well as the posterior aspect of the left upper lobe. The findings are worrisome for atypical pneumonia such as that related to COVID-19, influenza or RSV. Alternatively entities such as sepsis, pulmonary edema or allergic reaction can produce similar findings. Visualized upper abdomen: Negative. Bones/soft tissues: There are couple Schmorl's nodes involving the endplates in the thoracic spine. Heterogeneous bone density could be related to osteopenia. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolus. 2. Extensive areas of groundglass density in the lower lung fields and right upper lobe and left upper lobe as described above worrisome for atypical pneumonia, viral pneumonia, allergic alveolitis, drug reaction or pulmonary edema. Correlation with presentation recommended. Results were called to NATALIE RUTH MCCLANAHAN, M.D. At 2/19/2024 4:04 PM. Report E-Signed By: Steven Peck, MD at 2/19/2024 4:05 PM WSN:AMICRAD17

01_0686.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE HISTORY: Chest tightness intermittently for the past 2 weeks. Increased work of breathing with activity. Elevated d-dimer. COMPARISON: None. TECHNIQUE: Pulmonary embolus protocol: Thin-slice axial imaging of the chest was performed during maximal pulmonary arterial opacification with intravenous nonionic iodinated contrast. Sagittal and coronal reformats and axial, sagittal, and coronal MIP series were performed to aid in pulmonary embolus detection. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: 80 mL of IV Isovue-370. FINDINGS: PULMONARY ARTERIES: The pulmonary trunk is normal in caliber. Pulmonary arteries are adequately opacified to the subsegmental level. There are no pulmonary emboli in the visible pulmonary arteries. THORACIC INLET: Normal. AORTA AND ARCH BRANCH VESSELS: The ascending aorta measures 3.8 cm. No dissection. There is no atherosclerosis of the aorta. HEART/PERICARDIUM: The heart is normal. There is a small pericardial effusion that measures 7 mm in thickness. There is mild coronary artery calcification. MEDIASTINUM/HILA: Normal mediastinum. No lymphadenopathy. LUNGS/PLEURA: Trace right and small left pleural effusions. Mild adjacent atelectasis. Mild subsegmental right middle and right lower lobe atelectasis. Minimal atelectasis in the lingula. 5 mm average size right upper lobe pulmonary nodule (image 54 series 5). No pneumothorax. The airways are normal. UPPER ABDOMEN: Partially visualized cyst with a thin septation in the posterior right upper abdomen appears to be external to the liver on the sagittal and coronal views and may be an exophytic renal cyst. MUSCULOSKELETAL/VERTEBRA/BODY WALL: Mild spondylosis with flowing ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament, in keeping with diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH). Healed seventh lateral left rib fracture. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolism. 2. Trace right and small left pleural effusions with adjacent atelectasis. 3. Small pericardial effusion. 4. 5 mm right upper lobe pulmonary nodule. 5. Mild coronary artery calcification. 6. The ascending aorta measures 3.8 cm. No dissection. 7. Chronic findings as above. ---------- FLEISCHNER SOCIETY FOLLOW-UP GUIDELINES FOR NEWLY DETECTED INCIDENTAL NODULES IN PERSONS 35 YEARS OF AGE OR OLDER. *These recommendations do NOT apply to lung cancer screening, patients with immunosuppression or patients with a known primary malignancy. There is significant passive atelectasis resulting in near complete collapse of both lower lobes. There is no endobronchial lesion. Breast and axilla are otherwise unremarkable. Heart/vessels: Heart size within normal limits. There is mild deviation of the heart into the right aspect of the chest. The aorta and main pulmonary artery are normal in caliber. Pulmonary artery is adequately evaluated to the proximal segmental level four PE. There is no evidence of pulmonary embolism. Mediastinum: There are numerous enlarged mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes, for instance, a nodal conglomerate on series 6 image 236 measuring 3.8 x 2.0 cm. The left hilum is obscured given left pulmonary consolidation. There are mildly enlarged right hilar lymph nodes. There is a large hiatal hernia. Lungs/pleura: Right lung demonstrates scattered areas of groundglass opacification in the base with linear atelectatic change in the right middle lobe. There are several small apical pulmonary nodules, for instance, a 4 mm nodule on series 6 image 285. There is dense left lung consolidation/atelectatic change with debris within the left mainstem bronchus on series 6 image 207. None of the bronchi of the left lung are aerated. There is heterogeneous opacification of the left lung with relative hypoenhancement of the superior left lung. There is a moderate left effusion. There appears to be a pleural-based mildly enhancing mass on the left on image 81 of series 6 measuring 4.5 x 3.8 cm. There is associated mild cardiophrenic adenopathy (series 6 image 85). Visualized upper abdomen: Probable hepatic steatosis. Remainder of the visualized upper abdominal structures are normal. Bones/soft tissues: Discogenic degenerative changes throughout the spine. No evidence of acute osseous abnormality. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism to the proximal segmental level. 2. There appears to be a mildly enhancing pleural-based mass on the left measuring 4.5 x 3.8 cm. There is associated bulky mediastinal adenopathy, likely hilar adenopathy, left supraclavicular adenopathy, and mild cardiophrenic adenopathy. Findings are concerning for malignancy. Recommend tissue sampling. The left supraclavicular lymph nodes would be accessible percutaneously. 2. Dense left lung consolidation/atelectatic change with debris within the left mainstem bronchus. None of the bronchi of the left lung are aerated. There is a moderate left effusion. Findings may be postobstructive due to endobronchial mass, mucus plugging, or compression from mediastinal adenopathy. Consider pulmonology referral for consideration of bronchoscopy. These are of unknown chronicity involving T6, T12, and L2 the T12 and L2 compression fractures are present on the CT of the abdomen and pelvis dated March 9, 2018. IMPRESSION: 1. No CT evidence of pulmonary embolus. 2. Enlarged pulmonary trunk and RV/LV ratio suggests pulmonary hypertension. 3. Consolidation in the right middle lobe probably represents atelectasis/scarring. 4. Multiple compression fractures in the thoracic and lumbar spine are of unknown chronicity. 5. Rounded opacity in the right lung base seen on prior chest x-ray correlates with intra-abdominal fat from the abdomen. Report E-Signed By: G. Thomas Alexander, MD at 2/6/2024 3:38 PM WSN:AMICRAD31

PULMONARY ARTERIES/PULMONARY ARTERIAL VASCULAR TREE: Positive for pleural effusion fourth order pulmonary emboli in the left lower lobe (#2:68). Positive for second and third order pulmonary emboli to the RLL, RML, and RUL. Positive high-grade right heart strain. PE Risk Stratification: RV size in short axis: 4.8 cm LV size in short axis: 3.8 cm RV/LV ratio: Ratio > 0.9. Positive. Bowing of the septum: Yes Reflux of contrast into IVC: No Thrombus in right atrium or right ventricle: No Thrombus in transit across the atrial septum: No Positive high-grade right heart strain. 3-D RECONSTRUCTED IMAGES: MIP images confirm and further demonstrate the findings from the axial source images. No additional focal abnormalities are seen. IVC/SVC: Normal. MEDIASTINUM: Unremarkable. LYMPH NODES: Unremarkable. No enlarged lymph nodes. THYROID: Normal. PLEURA/PLEURAL SPACES: Unremarkable. UPPER ABDOMEN: Hepatic cysts. Splenectomy. Cholelithiasis. BONES: No acute bony change. SCOUT TOPOGRAM: Otherwise normal. IMPRESSION: 1. Positive pulmonary emboli with low-medium thrombus load. Positive high-grade right heart strain. 2. 4 mm right lower lobe pulmonary nodule. Consider 12 month follow-up chest CT if high risk patient, per Fleischner protocol. 3. Splenectomy. 4. Cholelithiasis. Findings discussed by D. Darrell Vaughn, MD directly with BRIAN MITCHELL STRICKLAND at 2/16/2024 11:09 PM. Findings acknowledged and understood. ---------- FLEISCHNER SOCIETY FOLLOW-UP GUIDELINES FOR NEWLY DETECTED INCIDENTAL NODULES IN PERSONS 35 YEARS OF AGE OR OLDER. *These recommendations do NOT apply to lung cancer screening, patients with immunosuppression or patients with a known primary malignancy. SOLITARY SOLID NODULE If nodule size is less than 6 mm: * Low risk patient: No routine follow-up. * High risk patient: Optional CT at 12 months. LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. There is a filling defect in the distal left inferior lobar artery extending into segmental branch (5/37, 902/183) suggestive of pulmonary embolus. No findings to suggest right heart strain. Thyroid: Visualized portions are unremarkable. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular adenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: Again seen multiple mediastinal hilar lymph nodes appear to have decreased in size, for example a subcarinal lymph node measuring 0.9 cm in short axis from previously 1.3 cm (5/31) and a right internal mammary node measuring 0.9 cm from previously 1.4 cm (5/24) when measured similarly. Interval decrease in size of right axillary node now measuring point 0.5 cm in short axis from previously 0.9 cm (5/19) and right retropectoral node measuring 0.7 cm in short axis from previously 0.9 cm (5/21). Upper Abdomen: Moderate hiatal hernia is overall unchanged. Innumerable liver lesions better characterized on recent PET/CT. No acute findings in the imaged abdomen. No evidence of right heart strain or pulmonary infarct. 2. Metastatic disease in the mediastinum and lungs appears overall stable compared to 11/30/2023. 3. Again seen metastatic disease involving the axial skeleton and liver better characterized on recent PET/CT. 02_0012.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE DATE OF EXAM: 02/07/2024, 1518. INDICATION: Sudden SOB and hypoxia. Rule out pulmonary embolism. COMPARISON: None available. TECHNIQUE: CT angiography of the chest was performed with contrast bolus timing allowing for adequate evaluation to the level of 70 pulmonary arteries using 70 mL of Isovue 370. Post-processing included the production of axial, coronal and sagittal multiplanar reformatted images and axial and coronal maximum intensity projections (MIPs). FINDINGS: Thyroid: Small right thyroid hypodense nodule measuring 0.3 cm. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.. Mediastinum and hila: No mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. Large hiatal hernia containing the pancreatic tail, stomach and mesenteric fat. The thoracic esophagus is unremarkable. Heart and great vessels: Extensive near occlusive central filling defects involving a small secondary right upper lobe artery and a subsegmental artery for the apical segment, the right interlobar artery, with extension to the right middle lobe and right inferior lobar pulmonary arteries as well as the anterior, medial and lateral basal segmental arteries. Additional occlusive thrombus involving apical posterior and anterior segmental arteries for the left upper lobe and the superior lingular artery, and the anterior medial basal and lateral basal segmental arteries of the left lower lobe. The heart is normal in size. There is flattening of the interventricular septum. The left heart chambers are also compressed by the large hiatus hernia. The main pulmonary artery diameter is at the upper limits of normal, measuring 2.9 cm in greatest transverse diameter. Mild ectasia of the ascending aorta, measuring 3.7 cm in greatest AP diameter. No coronary artery calcifications. No significant pericardial effusion. Lungs, airway and pleura: The central airways are patent. No bronchial wall thickening. Small passive atelectasis adjacent to the Bochdalek hernia, with additional small dependent atelectasis. Small solid nodule in the right base measuring 0.2 cm (series 7, image 265). No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Breast and axilla: Visualized breast tissue is symmetric. No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.. Bones and Soft Tissues: Prominent levocurvature of the lower thoracic spine. There is mild degenerative change of the spine. Mild depression of the superior vertebral endplates of T3 and T4. No aggressive osseous lesion. Superficial soft tissues are within normal limits. IMPRESSION: 1. Extensive bilateral near occlusive acute pulmonary embolism involving the bilateral pulmonary arteries with the most proximal involvement in the right interlobar artery, as described. 2. Flattening of the interventricular septum concerning for mild right heart strain. The left heart chambers are also compressed by the hiatus hernia. 3. Large hiatal hernia with herniation of pancreatic tail, stomach and peritoneal fat. No evidence of fat stranding to suggest incarceration. ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Findings were discussed with Anthony Rodriguez MD, by Daniel Montes, MD on 02/07/2024 at 3:33 PM. Critical readback was performed. CONTACT INFORMATION: This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. 02_0013.answer: CTA chest for PE DATE OF EXAM: 2/9/2024 INDICATION: Pulmonary embolism suspected, high probability. TECHNIQUE: Using multidetector CT, contrast enhanced chest CT was performed with contrast in pulmonary arterial phase. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. Three-dimensional coronal and sagittal MIP reconstructions were performed. CONTRAST: Isovue 370 100 mL COMPARISON: None FINDINGS: CTA: Contrast bolus timing allows for adequate evaluation to the level of the segmental pulmonary arteries. Extensive vascular wall calcifications along the main pulmonary artery with some extension to the left main pulmonary artery, may reflect postsurgical changes versus chronically altered flow dynamics in the setting of known underlying tetralogy of fallot. The left pulmonary artery is hypoplastic with an area of proximal stenosis with a minimal luminal diameter of approximately 0.3 cm (4/115). Just distal to this area of stenosis there is an eccentric filling defect along the pulmonary arterial wall probably chronic clot (902/173). No additional filling defects within the pulmonary arterial vasculature. Devices: Endotracheal tube terminates in the mid intrathoracic trachea. Enteric tube courses into the gastric fundus, below the field of view. Thyroid: In the inferior left thyroid there is a hypoattenuating nodule measuring 1.3 cm (902/141). Thoracic inlet: Nonspecific mild fat stranding the left greater than right superior mediastinal fat. No adenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: No mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. The thoracic esophagus is unremarkable. Heart and great vessels: Normal size of the heart. There is some reflux of contrast into the IVC and hepatic veins. Area of nodular calcification near the aortic root and pulmonary artery root may reflect postsurgical changes (902/162). No significant pericardial effusion. The ascending thoracic aorta measures up to 4.1 cm. Lungs, airway and pleura: Some debris is seen within the distal trachea. Diffuse groundglass abnormality with some superimposed septal thickening. Also, there is some peribronchial thickening and areas of mosaicism. A nodule seen in the posterior segment right apical lung measuring 0.7 x 0.4 cm. Other scattered smaller nodules. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Breast and axilla: Visualized breast tissue is symmetric. No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable. Bones and Soft Tissues: There is mild degenerative change of the spine. Dextrocurvature of the midthoracic spine. No aggressive osseous lesion. Superficial soft tissues are within normal limits. IMPRESSION: 1. No acute pulmonary embolism. Scattered thick calcifications along the main pulmonary artery and left main pulmonary artery, which appears stenosed. Findings are likely related to underlying tetralogy of Fallot and postprocedural changes. Distal to the left main pulmonary artery proximal stenosis there is a tiny eccentric filling defect probably a focus of chronic clot. 2. Some reflux of contrast is seen within the IVC/hepatic veins which may be related to elevated right heart pressures, possibly due to pulmonary artery stenosis/or pulmonary valve insufficiency. However, RV:LV ratio is normal. Follow-up results of performed same day echo. 3. Scattered groundglass abnormality and septal thickening likely reflects pulmonary edema. However, a superimposed infectious/inflammatory process is a consideration. 4. Mosaic attenuation is seen throughout both lungs, which may be related to an underlying pulmonary arterial vascular abnormality or small airways disease. 5. Right upper lobe nodule on average measuring 0.6 cm. Consider correlation with outside prior exams if available to confirm stability. Otherwise, recommend follow-up CT in 6-12 months. Critical findings and impression #1 were discussed with Dr. Asare Yaa and Dr. Andrew Ormsby of the primary team at 10:26 AM to 2/9/2024, via epic secure chat at 10:27 AM to 2/9/2024. CONTACT INFORMATION: This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. If there are any questions regarding this report or other radiology questions, please feel free to contact a radiologist directly at 720-848-RADS (7237) or if in the UCH hospital or clinics at 8-RADS. COMPARISON: CT 12/13/2023 and 10/12/2023 FINDINGS: Pulmonary arteries: Pulmonary artery trunk remains dilated measuring up to 4.3 cm. The left and right main pulmonary arteries are dilated and there is tortuosity and dilation of the central pulmonary vasculature. No evidence for pulmonary artery filling defect to the segmental level with limited assessment of the subsegmental branches. There is a small filling defect within a subsegmental branch extending into the lingula (series 6 image 147 and series 9 and four image 263 with more distal contrast opacification in the atelectatic lingula). The subsegmental filling defect is partially along the sidewall. Heart and great vessels: Heart is upper limits normal in size. Mild cardiomegaly between the right and left atria is not well-defined but unchanged and not well assessed by CT for underlying ASD. Thinning of the left ventricular myocardium at the apex can be seen with prior MI. There is lipomatous infiltration of the intra-atrial septum. Aorta is not diagnostically opacified but has normal course and caliber with mild scattered atherosclerotic plaque. Mild coronary artery calcifications. Mediastinum and hila: Prominent mediastinal fat. Unremarkable esophagus. Tiny hiatal hernia. There is significant narrowing collapse of the distal trachea and bilateral mainstem bronchi. Lungs and pleura: Mosaic attenuation. Scattered bronchial wall thickening with secretions and mucous plugging lower lobe bronchi. Persistent collapse the right middle lobe and partial collapse of the lingula. Increasing atelectasis and consolidation in the right lower lobe. Similar left basilar/lower lobe atelectasis. No pleural effusion, or pneumothorax. Thyroid (visualized portions): Normal. Thoracic inlet: Unremarkable. Chest wall: No enlarged lymph nodes.. Abdomen: Lobular contour of the liver and marked imaged attenuation indicative of steatosis and chronic hepatocellular disease. Bones: Osseous structures are diffusely demineralized. Multiple old rib fractures right lateral eighth rib fracture slightly offset is new from the prior but fracture margins appear somewhat ill-defined suggesting healing fracture. Moderate/severe multilevel degenerative changes of the spine. IMPRESSION: IMPRESSION: 1. Suspect a subtle subsegmental pulmonary artery embolus within the lingula. This could be acute to subacute. 2. Increasing atelectasis and/or consolidation in the right lower lobe secretions occluded in several lower lobe bronchi from mucous secretions. Persistent collapse of the right middle lobe and partial collapse of the lingula. Similar left basilar atelectasis. 3. Severe narrowing of the distal trachea and bilateral mainstem bronchi indicative of tracheal bronchomalacia. 4. Dilated pulmonary arteries indicative of pulmonary hypertension. 5. Hepatic steatosis and sequela of chronic hepatocellular disease. 6. Right lateral eighth rib fracture is new from 12/18/2023. This is of uncertain age and could be due to subacute. Results were discussed with Dr. LEMERY via phone at 1/13/2024 2:01 AM by Dr. Colantoni. A read back of two patient identifiers and impression occurred. More central appearing filling defect is noted within the right lower lobe medial basilar segmental branch (series 10, image 165). Otherwise, occlusive thrombus more distally within the medial and posteromedial basilar segmental and subsegmental branches. The main pulmonary artery is dilated up to 3.7 cm in Thyroid: Visualized portions are normal. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. No coronary artery calcifications. Lungs, airway and pleura: Central airways are patent. Patchy groundglass and consolidative opacities of bilateral lower lobes with more hazy groundglass within the upper lobes. Superimposed peripheral linear opacities within the upper lobes. Further evaluation limited. Bones and Soft Tissues: Generalized chest wall anasarca suggesting third spacing of fluids. No acute bony or focal soft tissue abnormality. IMPRESSION: 1. However, central filling defect is noted within the proximal right right lower lobe medial segment. While this focus may suggest acute PE, this may also represent resolving/evolving PE. No priors available for comparison. 2. Severe right atrial enlargement as well as right ventricular enlargement and reflux of contrast into the infrahepatic IVC, all suggesting elevated right heart pressures. There is resultant mass effect on the left atrium with narrowing. 3. Main pulmonary artery is dilated up to 3.7 cm suggesting pulmonary hypertension. 4. Basilar predominant groundglass and linear abnormality, most suggestive of atelectasis and pulmonary edema. Small component of lower lobe pneumonia not excluded given appearance. 5. Generalized anasarca and partially visualized abdominal ascites suggesting third spacing of fluids. Yes -Extravasation Type: Saline -Extravasation Amount (Please indicate type and amount i.e. 40 mL Saline, 60 mL Contrast): 30mL -Extravasation Site Right Forearm COMPARISON: CT PE 3/20/2023. Same-day chest x-ray. TECHNIQUE: Contrast enhanced chest CT performed during the injection of 60 mL of Isovue-370 according to PE protocol. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. FINDINGS: CTA FINDINGS: Contrast bolus timing is adequate to rule out pulmonary embolus to the subsegmental pulmonary arteries. Mild increase in dilation of the main pulmonary artery compared to prior examination, measuring up to 3.2 cm, previously 3.0 cm. Acute pulmonary embolus in the right lower lobar pulmonary artery. OTHER FINDINGS: Thyroid: No nodularity. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Heart and great vessels: The dual-lead left chest wall cardiac pacemaker/AICD, with its leads terminating in the right atrium and right ventricle. Redemonstrated is cardiomegaly with four-chamber enlargement. Postsurgical findings of prior left atrial appendage occlusion. Mild atherosclerotic calcifications throughout the thoracic aorta and its large caliber branches. Dilation of the ascending aorta, measuring up to 4.0 cm in caliber (measured on series 8/image 61), similar to prior. Mediastinum: Mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy, similar to prior. For example, enlarged left paratracheal lymph node measuring 1.0 cm short axis (5/112). Lungs, airways, and pleura: Fluid layers within the right mainstem bronchus. Opacification of distal airways in the bilateral lower lobes as well as the right middle lobe.Scattered bilateral groundglass pulmonary opacities. Tree-in-bud nodularity in the peripheral right upper lobe (for example, series 6/image 134). Near complete collapse of the right lower lobe with severe atelectasis of the right middle lobe as well. Consolidation within the left lower lobe. Large right and small left pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis of the dependent lungs bilaterally. Of note, all of these findings are strikingly similar to prior examination on 3/20/2023. Chest wall and axillae: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Timing of contrast bolus limits evaluation of the upper abdominal solid organs and bowel. No acute intra-abdominal abnormality. Small hiatal hernia. Bones and soft tissues: Mild degenerative changes of the imaged spine. No acute or aggressive-appearing osseous abnormality. Mild diffuse soft tissue edema. IMPRESSION: 1. Congestion of acute on chronic pulmonary embolus in the right lower lobar pulmonary artery. Streaky filling defect proximal to the presumed acute pulmonary embolus component likely represent sequela of old PE/pulmonary webs. No evidence of right heart strain. Complete collapse of the right lower lobe in its evaluation for pulmonary infarcts. 2. Stable cardiomegaly with reflux of contrast into the IVC consistent with cardiac dysfunction. No dilated main pulmonary artery consistent with pulmonary arterial hypertension. 3. Groundglass opacities throughout the left upper lobe concerning for atypical infection, aspiration, nonspecific pneumonitis or pulmonary edema. 4. New tree-in-bud opacities in the left upper lobe concerning for aspiration or atypical infection. Scattered groundglass opacities. 5. New near complete collapse of the right middle lobe. 6. Secretions in the right mainstem bronchus and multiple distal airways concerning for aspiration. 7. Large right and small left pleural effusions, similar to prior. 8. See above for additional chronic findings. ________________________________________________ The critical findings were discussed with Dr. Nemanja Vukovic via telephone by Dr. Chelsea Life of radiology on 2/15/2024 11:51 PM after confirming two patient identifiers. ________________________________________________ This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. Masslike consolidation posteriorly in the left upper lobe measuring 11.8 x 4.9 x 10.3 cm, which may represent postobstructive atelectasis, although underlying malignancy is not excluded. 5. Discrete 1.6 x 1.4 cm right lower lobe nodule suspicious for malignancy. 6. Ill-defined mid and basilar consolidative opacities and septal thickening suggesting organizing pneumonia. 7. 02_0049.answer: CTA chest for PE DATE OF EXAM: 2/9/2024 INDICATION: Pulmonary embolism suspected TECHNIQUE: Using multidetector CT, contrast enhanced chest CT was performed with contrast in pulmonary arterial phase. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. Three-dimensional coronal and sagittal MIP reconstructions were performed. CONTRAST: Isovue 370 55 mL COMPARISON: None FINDINGS: CTA: Contrast bolus timing allows for adequate evaluation to the level of the segmental pulmonary arteries. Multifocal pulmonary emboli are seen, some of them peripheral, listed below: in the medial basal segment of the right lower lobe lung (6/220), right middle lobe lobar artery with medial basal segmental extension (6/59), distal right main pulmonary artery, with possible extension into the upper lobe (902/150) and the lingular segments of the left upper lobe pulmonary arteries (6/109). Additional small distal segmental pulmonary emboli are noted in the lateral basal segments of left lower lobe lung (6/173). The main pulmonary artery is massively enlarged measuring up to 4.9 cm. There is septal flattening and the RV measures 3.7 cm. The LV measures 3.7 cm and there is reflux of contrast into the IVC and hepatic veins. Thyroid: Visualized portions are normal. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: A left paratracheal lymph node measures 1.2 cm (5/30). No additional enlarged mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes. Patulous esophagus. Heart and great vessels: Global enlargement of the heart severe coronary artery atherosclerotic calcification. Prominent aortic valvular and mitral annular calcifications. Potential left ventricular hypertrophy. No significant pericardial effusion. Normal size of the great vessels. RV: LV ratio: 1. Lungs, airway and pleura: The central airways are patent. No thickening and right upper lobe bronchiectasis. Mild diffuse groundglass abnormality with superimposed septal thickening. Superimposed small focal areas of consolidation, for instance in the posterior superior segment of the left upper lobe lung, there is a nodular opacity measuring 0.8 x 0.8 cm (6/87). Bilateral posterior compressive atelectasis. No suspicious pulmonary nodule. Moderate bilateral layering pleural effusions. Breast and axilla: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable. Bones and Soft Tissues: There is mild degenerative change of the spine. No aggressive osseous lesion. Superficial soft tissues are within normal limits. IMPRESSION: 1. Bilateral pulmonary emboli as described, some of them acute in the right lower lobe, and some of them likely chronic as described signs of mild right heart strain. However, there is global cardiomegaly and marked enlargement of the main pulmonary artery which is suspicious for chronic pulmonary hypertension with associated/superimposed right heart failure. Recommend evaluation by the pulmonary vascular disease clinic at 720.848.5300. 2. Mild bilateral groundglass with interlobular septal thickening likely representing pulmonary edema. Small burden of bilateral nodular/consolidative opacities which may be related to pulmonary edema or an infectious process. Recommend attention on follow-up. 3. Moderate right greater than left pleural effusions. 4. Prominently patulous esophagus, which suggests an increased risk for aspiration. Critical findings in impression point #1 were discussed with Dr. Amber Khanna at 4:56 PM on 2/9/2024, via epic secure chat by Dr. Parker Quimby. CONTACT INFORMATION: This exam was interpreted by a University of Colorado School of Medicine radiology physician. If there are any questions regarding this report or other radiology questions, please feel free to contact a radiologist directly at 720-848-RADS (7237) or if in the UCH hospital or clinics at 8-RADS. Post-processing included the production of axial, coronal and sagittal multiplanar reformatted images and axial and coronal maximum intensity projections (MIPs). Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: No mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. Large hiatal hernia with herniation of gastric contents into the mediastinum. No evidence of gastric volvulus. Heart and great vessels: There is opacification of the pulmonary arteries to the level of the subsegmental pulmonary arteries. There is central filling defect involving a left anterior upper lobe pulmonary artery (series 6, images 10 8-1 15. Partially centric filling defects involving right middle lobe and right lower lobe segmental arteries extending into subsegmental arteries (series 6, image 115 and 152). The right main pulmonary artery and ascending aorta diameter are within normal limits. Mild burden of coronary calcifications. No significant pericardial effusion. Normal hepatic attenuation. Smooth liver Bones and Soft Tissues: Mild degenerative change of the spine. No aggressive osseous lesion. Unremarkable soft tissues. IMPRESSION: 1. Partially eccentric-appearing filling defects and web like filling defects involving the right middle lobe and right lower lobe segmental arteries as above, likely subacute pulmonary emboli. However, there is also a central filling defect involving a left upper lobe anterior segmental pulmonary artery suspicious for acute pulmonary embolus. The main pulmonary artery is within normal limits. 2. There is minimal contrast reflux into the IVC and hepatic veins, which may indicate chronic right heart failure. 3. Upper abdomen: Visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable. Bones and Soft Tissues: There is mild degenerative change of the spine. No aggressive osseous lesion. Bilateral gynecomastia. IMPRESSION: IMPRESSION: 1. Small nonocclusive pulmonary embolus in a left lower lobe segmental branch. 2. 02_0081.answer: Procedure: CTA CHEST FOR PE - 02/18/2024, 0043. HISTORY: 68 years Female. Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, high prob Was there a contrast reaction? No Was there a contrast or saline extravasation? No. . IV contrast: 77 mL Isovue-370. Technique: Contiguous axial CTA images of the chest were performed after the administration of IV contrast. Post processed CTA MIP images of the pulmonary arteries were created and reviewed. The axial source images were also reviewed. IMMEDIATE ADVERSE EVENT: None Comparison: Chest x-ray dated 2/17/2024. Findings: Questionable mildly enlarged cardiac silhouette. There is flattening of the interventricular septum and asymmetric widening of the right heart chambers. Reflux of contrast into the IVC and hepatic veins. Advanced coronary atherosclerosis. Cannot exclude presence of a coronary stents. Mild calcification in the mitral valve. Mild calcifications in the aortic valve. Atherosclerosis in the aortic arch. Large irregularly-shaped lobulated conglomerate of simple fluid in the right epicardial region with largest lobule measuring up to 2.1 cm in short axis. Similar simple fluid density extends posteriorly, abutting the anterior aspect of the right middle lobe. It measures up to 3.6 x 1.9 cm, axial image 46 of series 5. Pulmonary artery caliber: Dilated measuring 3.7 cm. Large burden of pulmonary embolus extending from the distal aspect of the right main pulmonary artery into all three lobar branches with segmental and subsegmental extension throughout the right middle and lower lobes and segmental and subsegmental extension posterior segment of the right upper lobe. Moderate burden of pulmonary embolus extending involving the proximal left upper lobar branches as well as the segmental and subsegmental branches of the left lower lobe. Low lung volumes limit evaluation. Bibasilar dependent atelectasis. Faint peripheral groundglass opacities in the right lower lobe may represent developing pulmonary infarcts or may be related to atelectasis or atypical infection. Mosaic attenuation of the right lung consistent with PE. Streaky atelectasis versus scarring in the lingula. Pleural-based pulmonary nodule in the left lower lobe measuring up to 7 mm. There is no pneumothorax. There are no pleural effusions. Visualized portions of the upper abdomen demonstrate a small hiatal hernia. The visualized osseous structures are normal in appearance. IMPRESSION: Large burden right pulmonary emboli as above. Moderate burden left pulmonary emboli as above. Right heart strain with reflux of contrast into the IVC and hepatic veins consistent with cardiac dysfunction. Pulmonary arterial hypertension with dilated main pulmonary artery. Low lung volumes limit evaluation. Scattered mosaic attenuation of the lungs consistent with PE. Cannot exclude lower lobe developing infarcts. Multiloculated irregular shaped cystic structures in the right epicardial region. Differential considerations include bronchogenic cyst, pericardial cyst versus esophageal duplication cyst. Less likely consideration is necrotic epicardial lymphadenopathy. Evaluation is limited on pulmonary arterial phase imaging. Recommend nonemergent dedicated evaluation with contrast-enhanced CT chest (not PE protocol) or more accurate characterization.. Results were discussed with Dr. Steven Humphrey, MD via phone at 2/18/2024 2:58 AM by Dr. Medvid. A read back of two patient identifiers and impression occurred. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. Three-dimensional coronal and sagittal MIP reconstructions were performed. CONTRAST: Isovue 370 60 mL COMPARISON: None FINDINGS: CTA: Excellent opacification of the pulmonary arterial tree with acute saddle pulmonary embolism noted with extension into all lobar arteries, as well as into segmental and subsegmental branches throughout. Positive CT findings of right heart strain, with elevated RV:LV ratio >1, likely underlying right cardiac chamber enlargement and pulmonary artery dilation up to 3.8 cm. Thyroid: Visualized portions are normal. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: Mildly enlarged precarinal lymph node up to 15 mm likely reactive. No hilar adenopathy. Small hiatal hernia. Heart and great vessels: Again, suggestive enlargement of the right cardiac chambers. Left cardiac chambers normal in size. Normal pericardium. Mild primarily LAD coronary artery calcifications. Lungs, airway and pleura: The central airways are patent. Patchy groundglass opacities of the lingula. Subpleural linear opacities anteriorly within bilateral upper lobes with additional basilar predominant linear opacities, likely atelectasis or scarring. No dense consolidation. No definitive findings of underlying pulmonary infarct. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. 3 mm triangle nodule right middle lobe abutting the minor fissure, most suggestive of benign lymph node (series 6, image 157). Additional 3 mm nodule left upper lobe (series 6, image 141). Few additional smaller nodules are noted throughout. Breast and axilla: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: No acute abdominal abnormality. Bones and Soft Tissues: No acute findings. IMPRESSION: 1. Positive for acute saddle pulmonary embolism with extension into all lobar arteries and throughout numerous segmental and subsegmental branches. Positive CT findings of right heart strain. Main pulmonary artery dilated up to 3.8 cm. 2. Patchy groundglass opacities within the lingula, nonspecific, atypical appearance of pulmonary infarct, possibly infectious or inflammatory related such as aspiration. 3. Few scattered pulmonary nodules measuring up to 3 mm. Patient is high risk, follow-up CT in one year can be utilized to document stability or resolution. 4. Small hiatal hernia. Right IJ Port-A-Cath terminates in the low SVC. Again seen is a filling defect involving the right brachiocephalic vein and SVC, adherent to the distal aspect of the right internal jugular central line. Interval development of prominent collateral vasculature in the anterior chest and abdominal walls consistent with this thrombus being hemodynamically significant. 3. Age indeterminate superior endplate fracture deformity of T6 vertebral body, new since 11/18/2023. Correlate for recent history of trauma. 5. Prominent left axillary subcentimeter lymph nodes measuring up to 8 mm, not pathologically enlarged by size criteria. FINDINGS: CTA: Contrast bolus timing allows for adequate evaluation to the level of the segmental pulmonary arteries. Bulky mural thrombus with foci of calcification in the mid to distal main right pulmonary artery, extending into the interlobar pulmonary artery. There are eccentric and linear filling defects in the right lower lobe segmental and subsegmental branches, predominantly in the posterior and lateral basal segments. A few of these vessels are markedly attenuated. A few other tiny linear filling defects are present in the left lower lobe. Main pulmonary artery is measures 3.0 cm. Lungs, airway and pleura: The central airways are patent. Diffuse moderate bronchial wall thickening, with basilar predominant mucus plugging. Apical predominant emphysematous changes. Linear pleural parenchymal scarring with traction bronchiectasis, most notable in the right upper lobe. 4 mm left lower lobe solid pulmonary nodule (series 8, image 78). No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Breast and axilla: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Upper abdomen: Gallbladder is surgically absent. No acute abnormality. 02_0164.answer: EXAM DATE: 2/15/2024 12:31 AM PROCEDURES: CTA CHEST FOR PE CLINICAL DATA: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, high prob COMPARISON: None available. TECHNICAL DATA: Helical CT data through the chest after the uneventful intravenous administration of 75 ml of Isovue 370. Sagittal, and coronal reformats were created by the technologist. Post-processed, reconstructed multiplanar reformatted MIP images of the chest were also provided. All CT scans at this facility use dose modulation, iterative reconstruction, and/or weight based dosing when appropriate to reduce radiation dose to as low as reasonably achievable. FINDINGS: Mediastinum:Normal appearance of the thyroid. No mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. . Opacification of the pulmonary arteries is appropriate for evaluation of pulmonary embolus on this exam. No pulmonary arterial filling defects are seen to suggest pulmonary embolus. The pulmonary arteries and thoracic aorta are normal in course and caliber. Normal heart size. Normal appearance of the esophagus. Lungs and pleura: There is a 0.4 cm noncalcified nodule in the right upper lobe (image 69, series 6). Additional 0.4 cm noncalcified nodule seen in the left lower lobe (image 235, series 6. Additional 0.6 cm noncalcified nodule in the left lower lobe (image 272, series 6). 0.3 cm nodule in the peripheral left lower lobe (image 209, series 6). Additional noncalcified pulmonary nodule seen in the right middle lobe measuring 0.5 cm (image 248, series 6). Calcified nodules are seen in the medial right middle lobe. No pneumothorax or pleural effusions. No dense areas of consolidation are seen throughout the lungs. Normal appearance of the trachea and mainstem bronchi. Chest wall: No axillary lymphadenopathy. Normal appearance of the musculature of the chest wall. No soft tissue masses. Bones: No acute or suspicious osseous findings. Upper abdomen: Numerous calcified granuloma moderate seen scattered throughout the liver. Status post splenectomy. Remaining imaged hollow and solid organs of the visible portions of the upper abdomen show no acute or suspicious findings. IMPRESSION: 1. No pulmonary embolus or other acute cardiopulmonary findings. 2. Multiple noncalcified pulmonary nodules are seen throughout the lungs as above, the largest of which measures up to 0.6 cm in diameter. In a patient of unknown risk level with a solid nodule of 6-8 mm, recommend CT at 6-12 months. In a low-risk patient, then consider CT at 18-24 months. In a high-risk patient, if the nodule is stable at 6-12 months, recommend CT at 18-24 months. CITATION: MacMahon H, et al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. Radiology. 2017 Jul;284(1):228-243. Report E-Signed By: Jason M Allen, DO at 2/15/2024 1:45 AM WSN:RICRADHOME11

02_0171.answer: Patient Name: CHRIS VESTAL MR#: 002262922 Accession #: 31161647 Exam Description: CTA CHEST FOR PE Exam Date/Time: 1/22/2024 8:06 AM CT ANGIOGRAM OF THE PULMONARY ARTERIES TECHNIQUE: CT angiogram of the pulmonary arteries was performed utilizing 60 mL of Isovue-370 intravenous contrast. Post-processing was performed with creation of maximum intensity projection images (MIP). All CT scans at this facility use dose modulation, interactive reconstruction, and/or weight based dosing when appropriate to reduce radiation dose to as low as reasonably achievable. CLINICAL HISTORY: Follow-up pulmonary embolism. COMPARISON: 7/24/2023 FINDINGS: Study Quality: Degraded by quantum mottle artifact and poor contrast bolus timing such that subsegmental and segmental pulmonary emboli could be missed. Pulmonary arteries: Redemonstrated weblike embolus within the right lower lobar artery (series 17 image 174). Previously identified subsegmental pulmonary embolus at the left lower lobe is not definitely present on this exam, though visualization of the subsegmental pulmonary arteries is not possible on this exam. No acute central pulmonary embolus identified. The main pulmonary artery is not dilated. Thoracic inlet: No adenopathy. Axillae and thoracic wall: No adenopathy. Mediastinum: No adenopathy. Aorta: Non-dilated. Heart: Moderate to severe coronary artery calcifications. Central airways, lung parenchyma, and pleura: No central airway obstruction. No pleural effusion. Was a continuation of the pulmonary parenchyma. Upper abdomen: An incidental 2.6 cm renal lesion with attenuation 21-69 Hounsfield Units is seen in the mid left kidney (series 5, image 372). Musculoskeletal structures: Mild degenerative change of the spine without acute or aggressive lesion. IMPRESSION: IMPRESSION: 1. Degraded by quantum mottle artifact and poor contrast bolus timing such that subsegmental and segmental pulmonary emboli could be missed. 2. Redemonstrated chronic pulmonary embolus within the right lower lobar artery. Previously identified subsegmental pulmonary embolus at the left lower lobe is not definitely present on this exam, though visualization of the subsegmental pulmonary arteries is not possible on this exam. No acute central pulmonary embolus identified. 3. Mosaic attenuation of the pulmonary parenchyma which could be related to hypoinflation, though small vessel or small airway disease could have a similar appearance. 3. Left renal lesion measuring 2.6 cm has indeterminate imaging features, but is suspicious for neoplasm. Recommend further evaluation, preferably with MRI without and with intravenous contrast, or CT without and with IV contrast. Herts BR, et al. Management of the Incidental Renal Mass on CT: A White Paper of the ACR Incidental Findings Committee. J Am Coll Radiol. 2018 Feb;15(2):264-273. Bones/soft tissues: Degenerative changes of the shoulders and spine. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of acute pulmonary embolism. 2. Interval development of consolidation in the lingula as well as multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules, some of which have mild central cavitation, most prominent in the right lung. These are most likely infectious or inflammatory in etiology unless patient has prior history of cancer. ---------- FLEISCHNER SOCIETY FOLLOW-UP GUIDELINES FOR NEWLY DETECTED INCIDENTAL NODULES IN PERSONS 35 YEARS OF AGE OR OLDER. *These recommendations do NOT apply to lung cancer screening, patients with immunosuppression or patients with a known primary malignancy. MULTIPLE SOLID NODULES If nodule size is 8 mm: * Low risk patient ? CT at 3-6 months, then consider CT at 18-24 months if no change. * High risk patient ? CT at 3-6 months, then consider CT at 18-24 months if no change. LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. HIGH RISK PATIENT: Tobacco use, family history of lung cancer, upper pulmonary lobe location of nodule, presence of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, older age. MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. Radiology. Report E-Signed By: Nathan Miller, MD at 2/26/2024 9:29 PM WSN:AMICRAD45

Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: None. mL Isovue 370 COMPARISON: None. FINDINGS: Devices: None. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular adenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: No mediastinal or hilar adenopathy. Heart and great vessels: No pulmonary artery embolism. No pericardial effusion. The main pulmonary artery is normal in caliber. The ascending thoracic aorta is normal in caliber. Lungs, airway and pleura: Mild centrilobular emphysema. Left lower lobe nodule measuring 7 x 5 mm, previously 5 x 3 mm (image 117, series 17). Changes of prior left lower lobe wedge resection with associated volume loss. New peripheral consolidation left lower lobe. Other scattered nodules are similar. Air trapping in the medial right lower lobe is again seen. Bilateral bronchial wall thickening. Severe bronchial wall thickening in the lingula and left lower lobe multifocal filling defects in the left lower lobe bronchi. Axilla: Negative. Upper abdomen: Moderate hiatal hernia. Findings are consistent with bronchitis and associated atelectasis either related to underlying infectious or inflammatory process or aspiration in the setting of a moderate hiatal hernia. No pulmonary artery embolism. No findings to suggest chronic pulmonary artery embolism. Mild to moderate background centrilobular emphysema. Scattered bilateral pulmonary nodules are similar with increased size of a left lower lobe nodule now measuring 7 x 5 mm. Report E-Signed By: Joseph Carabetta at 1/25/2024 2:52 PM WSN:AMICRAD25 ADDENDUM: Pulmonary embolism findings discussed with covering physician by telephone on 8:21 AM. Report E-Signed By: Joseph Carabetta at 12/29/2023 8:34 AM WSN:AMICRAD25 CT ABDOMEN/PELVIS WITH CONTRAST, CTA CHEST FOR PE, CT BRAIN WITHOUT CONTRAST COMPARISON: None. HISTORY: Abdominal pain, acute, nonlocalized. Head trauma, minor. Pulmonary embolism suspected unknown d-dimer. TECHNIQUE: Axial noncontrast CT brain with coronal and sagittal reformats. Postcontrast axial CTA chest with coronal and sagittal reformats. Post contrast axial CT abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast. Coronal and sagittal reformats. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to patient size; or use of iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: 110 mL of IV Isovue-370. NONCONTRAST CT BRAIN FINDINGS: CSF SPACES: Ventricles, cisterns, and sulci are diffusely prominent consistent with volume loss which appears age-appropriate. No hydrocephalus, extra-axial hemorrhage, or mass. No midline shift. CEREBRUM: Patchy low-density in the cerebral white matter, commonly associated with chronic small vessel ischemic disease. No clear evidence of acute infarct by CT. No acute intracranial hemorrhage or cerebral edema. CEREBELLUM: No edema, hemorrhage, mass, acute infarction, or significant atrophy. BRAINSTEM: No edema, hemorrhage, mass, acute infarction, or significant atrophy. CALVARIUM: No acute calvarial fracture. The mastoid air cells are normally pneumatized. SINUSES: There is mild mucosal thickening in the left frontal sinus caudally, and moderate mucosal thickening causing partial opacification of the left ethmoid air cells. Mild right ethmoid sinus mucosal thickening. Moderate bilateral maxillary sinus mucosal thickening left greater than right. Probable maxillary antrostomies bilaterally. Nasogastric tube a completely imaged. ORBITS: Limited views are unremarkable. OTHER: Negative. CTA CHEST FINDINGS: CARDIAC: Heart was scanned during partial systole which makes RV LV ratio assessment somewhat difficult but the RV LV ratio is probably elevated about 1.0. There are mild coronary artery calcifications. Overall normal heart size with no pericardial effusion in the prominent epicardial fat. MEDIASTINUM/HILA: Enlarged with ill-defined subcarinal nodes, measuring up to about 17 mm short axis on the right series 5 image 171. Questionable esophageal wall thickening, limited assessment due to the nasogastric tube. VASCULATURE: Normal size right-sided aortic arch, with moderate aortic and great vessel calcifications. 3 cm pulmonary embolus within the distal left main pulmonary artery extending into lobar and segmental branches of left upper lobe. There is a branching pulmonary embolism in the lobar and segmental branches of the right lower lobe (5/163). Moderate-sized lobar or solid segmental level embolus left lower lobe (image 166). Endotracheal tube terminates 4.3 cm proximal to the carina. Small air emboli in the right external jugular and left internal jugular veins. At these size these are probably clinically insignificant. CHEST WALL: Unremarkable. No mass or axillary adenopathy. LUNGS/PLEURA: Trace pleural effusions, right larger than left, with mild nearby compression atelectasis. Widespread granulomatous calcifications in both lungs, consistent with sequela of old healed infection. Upon this background a few solid nodules are noted, largest about 6 x 13 mm in the right upper lobe on series 5 image 122. No consolidation. Diffuse bronchial wall thickening. Slightly asymmetric right greater than left irregular subpleural nodularity in the upper lobes, probably pleural parenchymal scarring. BONES: Moderate lower cervical spine and there are degenerative changes. Bridging ossifications and degenerative spurring in the thoracic spine. OTHER: Negative. CT ABDOMEN AND PELVIS FINDINGS: LIVER: Negative. BILIARY: There are cholecystectomy clips in the gallbladder fossa. No intrahepatic bile duct dilatation. There is a 5 mm calcified stone in the distal left common duct just above the ampulla, with mild common duct dilatation to about 12 mm. SPLEEN: Negative. PANCREAS: Age-appropriate pancreatic parenchymal atrophy. No evidence of acute pancreatitis. ADRENALS: Negative. KIDNEYS: Symmetric enhancement with no hydronephrosis or evidence of pyelonephritis. No appreciable stones by contrast-enhanced CT. GI/MESENTERY: Nasogastric tube terminates in the gastric body. There is descending and sigmoid colon diverticulosis. There is diffuse wall prominence of the under distended colon, without nearby fat stranding or fluid, probably artifact due to underdistention rather than mild acute colitis. Elsewhere no bowel wall thickening and no evidence for obstruction. No localized fat stranding or fluid collection. VASCULAR: Moderate vascular calcifications. Borderline size of the distal abdominal aorta, measuring up to 2.8 x 3.0 cm just proximal to the bifurcation. LYMPH NODES: Negative. BLADDER: Bladder wall trabeculation. Foley catheter with related air. PELVIC ORGANS: Enlarged prostate with prominent elevation of the bladder base. BONES: Degenerative changes in the lumbar spine with a few bridging ossifications. Mild hip osteoarthritis. No acute fractures. OTHER: Negative. IMPRESSION: IMPRESSION: 1. Moderate burden of acute pulmonary emboli in the left main pulmonary artery extending into lobar and segmental branches of the left upper lobe, right lower lobe and left lower lobe. There is mild elevation of the RV LV ratio which could indicate right heart strain. 2. Trace pleural effusions, right larger than left with mild nearby compression atelectasis. 3. Widespread granulomatous calcifications in both lungs, consistent with sequela of old healed infection. There are a few noncalcified pulmonary nodules which are indeterminate, largest is 9.5 mm average diameter. 3-6 month follow-up is recommended initially, please see below. 4. Enlarged subcarinal lymph nodes, nonspecific. 5. 5 mm calcified stone in the distal left common duct just above the ampulla with mild common duct dilatation to about 12 mm. No intrahepatic bile duct dilatation. 6. Diffuse wall prominence of the colon which is probably artifact due to underdistention rather than mild acute colitis. 7. Enlarged prostate with bladder wall trabeculation consistent with chronic bladder outlet obstruction. 8. Borderline size of the distal abdominal aorta measuring up to 3.0 cm. 9. Right-sided aortic arch. 10. Small air emboli in the right external jugular and left internal jugular veins. At these size these are probably clinically insignificant. ---------- FLEISCHNER SOCIETY FOLLOW-UP GUIDELINES FOR NEWLY DETECTED INCIDENTAL NODULES IN PERSONS 35 YEARS OF AGE OR OLDER. *These recommendations do NOT apply to lung cancer screening, patients with immunosuppression or patients with a known primary malignancy. MULTIPLE SOLID NODULES If nodule size is > 8 mm: * Low risk patient ? CT at 3-6 months, then consider CT at 18-24 months if no change. * High risk patient ? CT at 3-6 months, then consider CT at 18-24 months if no change. LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. HIGH RISK PATIENT: Tobacco use, family history of lung cancer, upper pulmonary lobe location of nodule, presence of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, older age. MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. There is poor opacification of the left segmental pulmonary artery branches. There is trace mixing artifact at the subsegmental branches of the right lower lobe. Enlarged caliber of the main pulmonary trunk. Thyroid: Visualized portions are unremarkable. Thoracic inlet: No supraclavicular adenopathy. Mediastinum and hila: No mediastinal or hilar adenopathy. Patchy consolidation groundglass opacities at the right middle lobe, and right lower lobe. There is dense consolidation at both dependent lower lobes which may represent atelectasis. CT CHEST FINDINGS: CARDIAC: Moderate cardiomegaly with right heart enlargement and straightening of the interventricular septum and an elevated RV LV ratio 0.95 suggestive of right heart strain. MEDIASTINUM/HILA: Unremarkable. No mass or significantly enlarged lymph nodes. VASCULATURE: Mild atherosclerotic calcifications. Enlarged main pulmonary artery, 3.9 cm transverse, suggesting pulmonary artery hypertension. Multiple acute pulmonary emboli are noted bilaterally. This includes moderate size pulmonary emboli within multiple lobar and signal branches of the right lower lobe, smaller segmental emboli in the right upper lobe, small moderate-sized lobar and segmental branch emboli in the left upper and left lower lobes. CHEST WALL: Unremarkable. No mass or axillary adenopathy. LUNGS/PLEURA: Small right and trace left pleural effusions, both layering dependently. There is subsegmental atelectasis in both lower lobes. There are parenchymal opacities consistent with pulmonary infarcts in the lingula measuring 4.3 cm on series 6 image 214 and the right lower lobe measuring about 2.5 cm image 251. Mild respiratory motion artifact bilaterally. BONES: Moderate degenerative changes in the visualized spine. Vertebral hemangioma in T5. CT abdomen and pelvis findings: There is mild motion artifact in the abdomen. LIVER: Negative. BILIARY: The gallbladder is unremarkable by CT and there is no bile duct dilatation. SPLEEN: Negative. PANCREAS: Negative. ADRENALS: Negative. KIDNEYS: Symmetric parenchymal enhancement. No hydronephrosis or pyelonephritis. There is a 7 cm mildly complex cyst in the upper pole right kidney (series 2 image 48), which is a thin peripherally calcified septation within it on coronal series 4 image 67 (Bosniak 2 benign lesion). Mildly complex cyst in the mid right kidney measuring 7.1 cm on series 2 image 65 with a thin peripheral partially calcified septation on series 2 image 68 (Bosniak 2/benign). Intermediate density probable proteinaceous cyst in the mid left kidney posteriorly measuring 4.7 cm image 46, measuring 38 Hounsfield units in density. GI/MESENTERY: There is no bowel wall thickening, mass or evidence for obstruction. No localized fat stranding, free air or fluid collection. VASCULAR: Moderate vascular calcifications. Normal size abdominal aorta. No fusiform morphologies but both common iliac arteries are larger than typical at 1.8 cm diameter, consistent with common iliac artery aneurysms. LYMPH NODES: Negative. BLADDER: 4.3 cm right posterolateral bladder diverticulum. PELVIC ORGANS: Enlarged prostate elevating the bladder base in the midline. Bilateral vasectomy clips. BONES: Advanced lumbar spine degenerative changes. Mild hip osteoarthritis. No concerning for bone or soft tissue lesions. OTHER: Negative. IMPRESSION: IMPRESSION: 1. Multiple acute pulmonary emboli bilaterally with findings suggesting right heart strain. 2. Pulmonary infarcts in the lingula and right lower lobe. 3. Small right and trace left pleural effusions. 4. No acute bowel pathology or cause for abdominal pain. 5. Benign Bosniak 2 renal cysts bilaterally do not require follow-up. There is an intermediate density technically indeterminate 4.7 cm lesion in the left kidney, favored to represent a benign cyst proteinaceous cyst, but differentiation from a solid lesion is not possible without pre and postcontrast technique. Targeted renal ultrasound follow-up recommended. 6. 4.3 cm right posterolateral bladder diverticulum. 7. Enlarged prostate. 8. 1.8 cm common iliac artery aneurysms bilaterally. MEDIASTINUM/HILA: Enlarged AP window lymph node, 1.5 x 2.9 cm six image 90, previously 1.2 x 2.5 cm. Moderately enlarged right hilar node, 2.0 x 2.8 cm on image 120, previously 1.4 x 1.8 cm. CHEST WALL: No mass or adenopathy. Right breast skin thickening was noted on recent CT chest. The breasts are cropped from the field-of-view on this study. Multiple new upper lobe predominant pulmonary nodules, measuring up to about 2 x 5 mm in the right upper lobe series 6 image 64. BONES: Moderate thoracic spine degenerative changes. No concerning bone lesions. LIMITED ABDOMEN: Granulomatous calcification in the spleen. A completely imaged left renal cyst. Vascular calcifications. Dilated bile ducts due to choledocholithiasis noted on today's abdominal CT. OTHER: Negative. IMPRESSION: IMPRESSION: 1. Multiple acute pulmonary emboli bilaterally with associated pulmonary infarct in the right upper lobe posterior segment. 2. Elevated RV LV ratio suggesting right heart strain. 3. Multiple new upper lobe predominant pulmonary nodules measuring up to about 2 x 5 mm in size, probably infectious/inflammatory. Three month follow-up recommended given the multiplicity and moderate background emphysema, as metastatic disease cannot be excluded. 4. Enlarging mediastinal and right hilar lymph nodes, and these could be reactive or metastatic. 5. Dilated bile ducts due to choledocholithiasis noted on today's abdominal CT. 6. Lungs/pleura: 3 mm nodule in the right lung apex, 6/233, is new 1.1 x 2.0 cm consolidation versus nodularity in the right upper lung, 6/193, was not present previously. Other subpleural nodules scattered throughout the lungs measuring up to 8 mm are new, 6/142.. Visualized upper abdomen: Negative. Bones/soft tissues: New since prior CT, there is superior endplate T1 deformity, T5 compression causing approximately 40% height loss and no significant retropulsion and marked T11 compression causing near vertebral plana anteriorly with approximately 6 mm retropulsion of the superior fragments posteriorly.. IMPRESSION: IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism to the lobar pulmonary arteries. 2. Interval increase in caliber of the ascending thoracic aorta, now measuring 4.9 cm. 3. 02_0355.answer: CT: CTA CHEST FOR PE HISTORY: PE hx, worse pain 64 years Female. COMPARISON: Chest CTA of 12/29/2023. No other chest CTs dating back to 01/29/2021. TECHNIQUE: CT angiography of the chest with intravenous contrast. Sagittal, coronal and slab 3D MIP reconstructions. DOSE OPTIMIZATION: One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: 80 cc Isovue-370 IV contrast. No adverse contrast reaction reported. FINDINGS: LOWER NECK: Normal. HEART/PERICARDIUM: Normal heart size. Coronary atherosclerosis and/or stents. No pericardial effusion. AORTA/GREAT VESSELS: Minimal calcific atherosclerotic vascular disease. No thoracic aortic aneurysm or dissection. PULMONARY ARTERIES/PULMONARY ARTERIAL VASCULAR TREE: Near-complete resolution of previously demonstrated thrombus in the first order pulmonary artery supplying the right lower lobe. Pulmonary arteries are patent. No high-grade right heart strain. PE Risk Stratification: RV size in short axis: 3.8 cm LV size in short axis: 4.6 cm RV/LV ratio: 0.82. Negative. Bowing of the septum: No Reflux of contrast into IVC: No Thrombus in right atrium or right ventricle: No Thrombus in transit across the atrial septum: No Negative high-grade right heart strain. 3-D RECONSTRUCTED IMAGES: MIP images confirm and further demonstrate the findings from the axial source images. No additional focal abnormalities are seen. VENOUS VASCULATURE: Thrombosed SVC. Prominent collateral venous collaterals. The previous examination, the SVC was nearly completely occluded. On today's exam, only a trickle of contrast passes through the SVC. MEDIASTINUM: Large sliding hiatal hernia. LYMPH NODES: Unremarkable. No enlarged lymph nodes. THYROID: Normal. PLEURA/PLEURAL SPACES: Enlarging moderate right pleural effusion. No left pleural effusion. No pneumothorax. TRACHEA/BRONCHI: Normal. LUNGS: Compressive atelectasis in the right lower lung. Stable 9 mm groundglass nodule in the right lower lobe (#5:40), unchanged since 2021. New indeterminate 4 mm anterior right upper lobe pulmonary nodule (#5:62). Underlying hyperinflation of lungs. CHEST WALL/SOFT TISSUES: Prominent varices. BREASTS: No CT abnormality demonstrated. UPPER ABDOMEN: Cholecystectomy. Top normal spleen size. BONES: No acute bony change. Stable lower anterior cervical spine fusion. Stable lower thoracolumbar posterior spinal fusion. Intact orthopedic hardware without evidence of loosening or fracture. SCOUT TOPOGRAM: Otherwise normal. IMPRESSION: 1. Near-complete resolution of pulmonary emboli. Small residual thrombus in the first order pulmonary artery supplying the right lower lobe. No high-grade right heart strain. 2. Enlarging moderate right pleural effusion. 3. New 4 mm RUL pulmonary nodule. Stable 9 mm RLL groundglass pulmonary nodule, unchanged since 2021. Advise 6 month follow-up chest CT for Fleischner protocol. 4. Stable large sliding hiatal hernia. ---------- FLEISCHNER SOCIETY FOLLOW-UP GUIDELINES FOR NEWLY DETECTED INCIDENTAL NODULES IN PERSONS 35 YEARS OF AGE OR OLDER. *These recommendations do NOT apply to lung cancer screening, patients with immunosuppression or patients with a known primary malignancy. SOLITARY GROUNDGLASS NODULES If nodule size is less than 6 mm: * No routine follow-up. If nodule size is greater than 6 mm: * CT at 6-12 months to confirm persistence, then CT every 2 years until 5 years LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. HIGH RISK PATIENT: Tobacco use, family history of lung cancer, upper pulmonary lobe location of nodule, presence of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, older age. MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. Radiology. Report E-Signed By: David D Vaughn at 2/8/2024 11:01 PM WSN:AMICRAD71

02_0356.answer: CT: CTA CHEST FOR PE HISTORY: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, positive D-dimer 63 years Female. COMPARISON: Chest CT of 02/07/2023. TECHNIQUE: CT angiography of the chest with intravenous contrast. Sagittal, coronal and slab 3D MIP reconstructions. DOSE OPTIMIZATION: One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: 50 cc Isovue-370 IV contrast. No adverse contrast reaction reported. FINDINGS: LOWER NECK: Normal. HEART/PERICARDIUM: Normal heart size. Coronary atherosclerosis and/or stents. AORTA/GREAT VESSELS: Minimal calcific atherosclerotic vascular disease. No thoracic aortic aneurysm. PULMONARY ARTERIES/PULMONARY ARTERIAL VASCULAR TREE: Dilated main pulmonary artery to 3.7 cm, compatible with pulmonary arterial hypertension. Positive pulmonary emboli. * Large saddle thrombus at the bifurcation of the LEFT main pulmonary artery. * Near-complete occlusive thrombus in the first second and third order artery supplying the LEFT lingula. * Nonocclusive thrombus involving the first second and third order pulmonary artery supplying the LEFT upper lobe. * Near-complete occlusive thrombus involving the first, second, third and fourth order artery supplying the LEFT lower lobe. * Large nonocclusive saddle thrombus at the bifurcation of the RIGHT main pulmonary artery. * Nonocclusive first, second, and third order thrombi are demonstrated in the RUL, RML, and RLL. PE Risk Stratification: RV size in short axis: 5.9 cm LV size in short axis: 3.6 cm RV/LV ratio: Ratio > 0.9. Positive. Bowing of the septum: Yes Reflux of contrast into IVC: No Thrombus in right atrium or right ventricle: No Thrombus in transit across the atrial septum: No Positive high-grade right heart strain. 3-D RECONSTRUCTED IMAGES: MIP images confirm and further demonstrate the findings from the axial source images. No additional focal abnormalities are seen. IVC/SVC: Normal. MEDIASTINUM: Unremarkable. LYMPH NODES: Unremarkable. No enlarged lymph nodes. THYROID: Normal. PLEURA/PLEURAL SPACES: Small left pleural effusion. No pneumothorax. TRACHEA/BRONCHI: Normal. LUNGS: * Enlarging nonspecific 5.4 x 2.8 x 4.9 cm (37 mL) wedge-shaped opacity in the superior segment of the left lower lobe with central cavitation. On the previous exam of 2023, this lesion measured 4.2 x 2.2 x 4.8 cm (22 mL). * New 2.8 x 2.0 cm irregular opacities in the periphery of the right upper lobe. * Resolution of previously demonstrated 1.3 cm RLL nodule. * Resolution of nodular densities in the periphery of the right lower lobe. * Resolution of nodular densities in the left upper lobe, medial right upper lobe. * Resolution of nodular densities in the medial right lung base, medial left upper lobe, and lateral right lower lobe. CHEST WALL/SOFT TISSUES: Unremarkable. BREASTS: * There is a new large 4.7 x 3.7 x 5.0 cm density (5-10 HU) in the inner right breast. This may represent a large cyst. However its margins are indistinct, which is concerning for malignancy. Advise diagnostic bilateral mammogram and diagnostic breast ultrasound to exclude breast cancer. * Prior surgery in the outer right breast. UPPER ABDOMEN: Cholecystectomy. BONES: No acute bony change. Stable multilevel thoracic spondylosis, arthrosis and degenerative disc disease. Stable old small thoracic body compression fractures. SCOUT TOPOGRAM: Otherwise normal. IMPRESSION: 1. Positive for pulmonary embolism with large thrombus load. Secondary high-grade right heart strain and pulmonary arterial hypertension. 2. Enlarging cavitary wedge-shaped opacity in the superior segment of the left lower lobe. Diagnostic considerations include recurrent pneumonia (including atypical pneumonia such as fungal pneumonia), pulmonary infarct related to the pulmonary embolism, and malignancy/metastatic disease. 3. New 5 cm density in inner right breast. Advise diagnostic bilateral mammogram and diagnostic ultrasound on a nonemergent basis to exclude breast cancer. 4. Nonspecific small irregular opacities in the periphery of the right upper lobe, probably related to impression #2. 5. Resolution of multiple previously demonstrated nodular densities, probably representing resolution of pneumonia or treated metastasis. Findings discussed by D. Darrell Vaughn, MD directly with DARLENA DARLA MICHELLE LEINS at 2/9/2024 4:50 AM. Findings acknowledged and understood. Report E-Signed By: David D Vaughn at 2/9/2024 4:51 AM WSN:AMICRAD71
