02_0360.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE Provided history: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, positive D-dimer Additional pertinent history: none TECHNIQUE: Pulmonary embolus protocol - Thin-slice axial imaging of the chest was performed during maximal pulmonary arterial opacification with intravenous nonionic iodinated contrast. 3D coronal slab MIPs and 2D reconstructions in the coronal and sagittal planes were performed to aid in pulmonary embolus detection. Representative images have been stored on PACS. EKG gating: no Contrast: 64 ml Isovue 370 One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. COMPARISON STUDIES: Plain films yesterday. FINDINGS: Angiographic Findings: Pulmonary arteries: There is no embolism to the main, right or left or lobar arteries. Beyond this point, the dependent vessels are very difficult to assess due to extensive breathing motion artifact. Based upon reconstructed sagittal and coronal series, I see no obvious peripheral emboli. Thoracic aorta: negative. Additional non-angiographic findings: Lungs / pleura / hila: There are no segmental or larger areas of consolidation. Indistinct nonconfluent nodular densities noted dependent right lung base and in the mid right upper lobe, likely inflammatory possibly infectious in origin. I think metastatic disease is unlikely given the absence of similar changes on the left. In addition, there is a mildly enlarged right hilar node short diameter 16 mm. No similar finding in the left hilum. Lower neck: negative Mediastinum: Scattered small likely benign reactive lymph nodes. One lymph node in the subcarinal space is borderline prominent short diameter 15 mm. Heart / pericardium: negative Other Vessels: Mild LAD calcification. Body wall: negative Upper abdomen: negative Lymph nodes: See above. No significant additional lymph node findings. Bones: Multiple old Schmorl's nodes in the thoracic spine. No lytic or blastic osseous lesions. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of central embolism to the lobar level. Limited assessment of peripheral vessels due to breathing motion artifact but no obvious peripheral emboli. 2. No segmental or larger areas of consolidation. Indistinct patchy nodular density just above the right lung probably infectious or inflammatory in origin. Suggest follow-up chest radiograph to document appropriate resolution. Report E-Signed By: Richard Pacini, MD at 2/10/2024 4:17 PM WSN:DS7POUDRE

02_0363.answer: EXAM: CTA CHEST FOR PE CLINICAL DATA: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, positive D-dimer TECHNICAL DATA: Contrast-enhanced CT pulmonary CT angiogram of the chest was performed with IV contrast. Multiplanar reconstructions were generated. All CT data was transferred to a 3D workstation for multiplanar reformation and 3D reconstruction under concurrent physician supervision. All CT scans at this facility use dose modulation, iterative reconstruction, and/or weight based dosing when appropriate to reduce radiation dose to as low as reasonably achievable. COMPARISON: Radiographs February 11, 2024 FINDINGS: Left ACJ again noted. Scattered atherosclerotic calcifications including coronary artery calcifications. Cardiomegaly. Filling defects are seen in the main or lobar pulmonary arteries or in the upper lobe segmental pulmonary arteries. The lower lobe segmental branches are poorly opacified and cannot be evaluated. No thoracic lymphadenopathy. Small bilateral pleural effusions. No pericardial effusion. Mild bilateral interstitial edema Mild to moderate centrilobular emphysema. There are additional patchy opacities in the middle lobe, lingular, and less prominent in the basal lower lobes. The central airways appear patent. No acute abnormalities in the upper abdomen. No acute bone abnormalities. IMPRESSION: Impression: No central or distal upper lobe pulmonary embolism identified. The right and left lower lobe segmental branches are poorly opacified resulting in suboptimal evaluation for pulmonary embolism. Cardiomegaly Mild bilateral interstitial edema Patchy opacities in the basal regions of the right middle lobe and lingular, and less prominently throughout the basilar right left lower lobes, most consistent with pneumonia. Report E-Signed By: Jeffrey Gronkiewicz, MD at 2/11/2024 10:16 AM WSN:GVM1PACSDR01

02_0365.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE DATE OF EXAM: 02/11/2024, 2311 INDICATION: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, positive D-dimer TECHNIQUE: Using multidetector CT, contrast enhanced chest CT was performed. Three-dimensional (MIP) reconstructions were performed. Three-dimensional coronal and sagittal MIP reconstructions were performed. All CT scans at this facility use dose modulation, iterative reconstruction, and/or weight based dosing when appropriate to reduce radiation dose to as low as reasonably achievable. CONTRAST: Isovue 370 75 mL COMPARISON: CT chest dated 10/29/2022 FINDINGS: Suboptimal evaluation due to motion artifact. Suboptimal evaluation due to streak artifact from retained venous contrast CTA: Contrast bolus timing allows for adequate evaluation to the level of the segmental pulmonary arteries. No filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolus. Normal caliber of the main pulmonary trunk. Thyroid: Visualized portions are unremarkable. Thoracic inlet: Bulky left thoracic lymphadenopathy measuring 4.4 x 2.8 cm on series 17 image 60. Interval increase in size since 10/29/2022 The mass encases the left common carotid and left subclavian arteries Mediastinum and hila: Poor evaluation for mediastinal or hilar adenopathy due to the phase of contrast, though mediastinal lymphadenopathy is suspected. Thoracic esophagus is unremarkable. Heart and great vessels: Heart is normal in size. No pericardial effusion. The bolus was injected at the left upper extremity, but no contrast is seen at the left subclavian vein, innominate vein, or superior vena cava. Numerous contrast opacified venous collaterals of the chest wall and azygous/hemiazygous system. Lungs, airway and pleura: Central airways are patent and normal in caliber. There is a suspected mass at the left upper lobe adjacent to the hilum, measuring 3.6 x 6.8 x 6.7 cm, series 7 image 101 series 5 image 127. There is invasion of the mediastinal fat at the level of the AP window. There is a moderate left and trace right pleural effusion. There is suspected pulmonary edema, new since 2022, on a background of chronic lung disease which is not significant changed 10/29/2022. There is atelectasis at the left lower lobes along the effusions. Breast and axilla: No chest wall mass. Gynecomastia. No axillary adenopathy. Upper Abdomen: Visualized portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable. Bones/Soft tissues: L2 superior endplate compression fracture suspected. No thoracic compression fracture. Mild multilevel thoracic spondylosis. No lytic lesion. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism to the segmental pulmonary arterial level. 2. A mass at the left upper lobe adjacent to the hilum, measuring 3.6 x 6.8 x 6.7 cm. Suspect primary neoplasm. There is invasion of the mediastinal fat at the level of the AP window. 3. Bulky left thoracic inlet lymphadenopathy, likely represents metastasis. This results in obstruction of the left subclavian/innominate vein. Numerous contrast opacified venous collaterals of the chest wall and azygous/hemiazygous system. 4. The left thoracic inlet mass encases the left common carotid and subclavian arteries. 5. Moderate left and trace right pleural effusions, possibly a malignant effusion on the left. 6. A background of chronic lung disease, with suspected superimposed pulmonary edema. Report E-Signed By: David Raban, MD at 2/11/2024 11:32 PM WSN:RICRADHOME26

02_0371.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE HISTORY: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, high prob TECHNIQUE: CTA chest with intravenous contrast attention to pulmonary arteries. Sagittal, coronal and slab 3D MIP coronal reconstructed images were also created for further evaluation and interpretation. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: 80 mL Isovue-370. COMPARISON: None. FINDINGS: Heart/vessels: Satisfactory opacification of the pulmonary arteries. Small-volume saddle pulmonary filling defect with additional small/moderate volume defects extending into the left lower lobe segmental and subsegmental branches. Additional small/moderate volume filling defects within segmental branches of the left upper lobe, right upper lobe, right middle lobe, and right lower lobe. Overall, moderate volume filling defects. No definitive evidence for right heart strain although evaluation is suboptimal secondary to motion. Mediastinum: Small thyroid nodules measuring up to approximately 1.2 cm. Lymph nodes: Negative. Lungs/pleura: Interstitial consolidation within the left lower lobe, most compatible with a developing pulmonary infarct. Small adjacent pleural effusion and atelectasis. 6 x 6 mm solid left lower lobe pulmonary nodule (image 172 of series 7). 3 mm subpleural right middle lobe pulmonary nodule (image 184). Visualized upper abdomen: Mild atherosclerosis. No free fluid or lymphadenopathy.. Peripherally calcified splenic artery aneurysm measuring up to 8 mm. Bones/soft tissues: No acute or concerning abnormality. IMPRESSION: 1. Positive for pulmonary embolus with overall moderate volume filling defects, as above. No definitive evidence for right heart strain although evaluation is suboptimal secondary to motion. Echocardiogram is suggested for further evaluation. 2. Interstitial consolidation within the left lower lobe, most compatible with a developing pulmonary infarct. Small adjacent pleural effusion and atelectasis. 3. Incidental note of a small pulmonary nodules, the largest of which measures up to 6 mm. Please see follow-up recommendations, below. 4. Additional incidental/chronic findings, as above. RECOMMENDATION Pulmonary nodule: Non-contrast chest CT at 3-6 months is recommended. If the nodules are stable at time of repeat CT, then future CT at 18-24 months (from today's scan) is considered optional for low-risk patients, but is recommended for high-risk patients (Per Fleischner Society guidelines). Thyroid nodule: No follow-up recommended unless deemed clinically necessary. Results were discussed with BRANDON MICHAEL UTTLEY at 2/13/2024 4:08 PM. Report E-Signed By: Nicholas Constantine, MD at 2/13/2024 4:08 PM WSN:AMICRAD16

02_0401.answer: CTA CHEST FOR PE HISTORY: Pulmonary embolism (PE) suspected, positive D-dimer TECHNIQUE: CTA chest with intravenous contrast attention to pulmonary arteries. Sagittal, coronal and slab 3D MIP coronal reconstructed images were also created for further evaluation and interpretation. One of the following dose optimization techniques was utilized in the performance of this exam: Automated exposure control; adjustment of the mA and/or kV according to the patient's size; or use of an iterative reconstruction technique. Specific details can be referenced in the facility's radiology CT exam operational policy. CONTRAST: 75 mL Isovue-370. COMPARISON: None. FINDINGS: PULMONARY CTA FINDINGS: Limited evaluation due to motion artifact.. There is no acute pulmonary embolism to the first subsegmental pulmonary artery level. OTHER FINDINGS: Support Devices: None. Heart/Pericardium/Great Vessels: Cardiac size is mildly enlarged. There is no calcific coronary artery atherosclerosis. There is no pericardial effusion. There is mild thoracic aortic and branch vessel atherosclerosis, portions calcific. The main pulmonary artery is dilated measuring up to 3.9 cm in diameter. Pleural Spaces: The pleural spaces are clear. Mediastinum/Hila: There is no mediastinal or hilar lymph node enlargement. Neck Base/Chest Wall/Diaphragm/Upper Abdomen: Enlarged left thyroid lobe with a potential 2.4 cm hypoattenuating lesion in the left inferior thyroid lobe (9/183). There is calcific atherosclerosis of the right axillary artery. There is no supraclavicular or axillary lymph node enlargement. Limited imaging through the upper abdomen is within normal limits. Mild degenerative change is present in the spine. Lungs/Central Airways: A trace amount of dependent mucous cyst noted in the posterior trachea. No focal consolidation. A 5 mm nodule is noted in the basilar right lower lobe (7/199), and two adjacent 4 mm nodules are noted in the posterior apical left upper lobe (7/72, 67). IMPRESSION: No acute pulmonary embolism to the first subsegmental level. The main pulmonary artery is dilated, which can be seen in setting of pulmonary hypertension. Mild cardiomegaly. Calcific atherosclerosis of thoracic and visualized abdominal aorta, which is more than expected for the patient's age. Enlarged left inferior thyroid lobe with a potential 2.4 cm nodule. Follow-up with thyroid ultrasound is recommended. Pulmonary nodules measuring up to 5 mm, for which follow-up is recommended based on the following Fleischner guideline. Fleischner Society 2017 Guidelines*: For patients at low clinical risk** in whom multiple incidental solid nodules measuring < 6 mm are identified, no routine imaging follow-up is suggested. For patients at high clinical risk** in whom multiple incidental solid nodules measuring < 6 mm are identified, a follow up chest CT at 12 may be considered (particularly if one or more nodules are upper lobe in location or have suspicious morphology) depending on comorbidity and patient preferences. Report E-Signed By: Lucy Lester, MD at 2/23/2024 10:12 PM WSN:AMICRAD90

CHEST WALL: Unremarkable. No mass or axillary adenopathy. LUNGS/PLEURA: No significant pleural-parenchymal abnormalities. No consolidation, edema, effusion or significant bronchial wall thickening. Benign-appearing 3 mm solid right upper lobe nodule series 7 image 155. Benign calcified granuloma in the right lung apex. BONES: Mild mid thoracic spine endplate spurring. LIMITED ABDOMEN: Calcified gallstones, a completely imaged. OTHER: Negative. IMPRESSION: 1. There is no evidence of acute pulmonary embolus to the segmental arterial level. No cause for symptoms identified. 2. Cholelithiasis. Gallstones and gallbladder are incompletely imaged. 3. 3 mm benign-appearing right upper lobe nodule. No follow-up recommended. ---------- FLEISCHNER SOCIETY FOLLOW-UP GUIDELINES FOR NEWLY DETECTED INCIDENTAL NODULES IN PERSONS 35 YEARS OF AGE OR OLDER. *These recommendations do NOT apply to lung cancer screening, patients with immunosuppression or patients with a known primary malignancy. SOLITARY SOLID NODULE If nodule size is < 6 mm: * Low risk patient ? No routine follow-up. * High risk patient ? Optional CT at 12 months. LOW RISK PATIENT: Minimal or absent history of tobacco use and of other known risk factors. HIGH RISK PATIENT: Tobacco use, family history of lung cancer, upper pulmonary lobe location of nodule, presence of emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, older age. MacMahon H, Naidich DP, Goo JM, et al. Guidelines for Management of Incidental Pulmonary Nodules Detected on CT Images: From the Fleischner Society 2017. Radiology. uchnipn Report E-Signed By: Joseph Carabetta at 2/26/2024 10:32 AM WSN:AMICRAD25

No acute pulmonary embolus is identified throughout the right or left lungs. Dilation of the main and central pulmonary arteries is again noted. Sagittal and coronal reconstructed images are presented. 3-D MIP sequences are also presented which were performed on a separate workstation by the technologist. One or more of the following dose reduction techniques were utilized: automated exposure control, mA and/or kV adjustment according to the patient's size, and or iterative reconstruction technique. COMPARISON: CT chest 2/6/2024, CT abdomen and pelvis 2/4/2024 FINDINGS: Technically limited exam, with incomplete evaluation of the subsegmental pulmonary arteries. Vessels:Multiple filling defects involving segmental branches of the pulmonary arteries bilaterally with overall small clot burden on limited evaluation. Imaging of the subsegmental vessels is suboptimal. Lungs:Inspissated material within the trachea and bilateral main bronchi. New patchy consolidation within the medial and inferior aspect of the right upper lobe. Increased partial atelectasis of the right lower lobe secondary to pleural effusion. New post obstructive consolidation in the anterior aspect of the right upper lobe which is relatively hypodense in attenuation. No internal gas. Unchanged spiculated nodule in the right middle lobe. No significant pulmonary interstitial edema. New partial atelectasis of left lower lobe secondary to pleural effusion. Pleural space:Increase moderate right pleural effusion and new small left pleural effusion. No pneumothorax. No obvious pleural implants. Heart and mediastinum: No obvious right heart strain. Moderate biatrial enlargement with likely associated reflux of contrast into the hepatic veins. No pericardial effusion. Decreased size of mediastinal mass centered in the right upper paratracheal region that now measures 5.6 x 5.7 cm, previously 7.9 x 6.5 cm. Bones:Unchanged compression fractures of T10 and T11. No acute fracture. Chest wall:Unremarkable. Upper abdomen:Unremarkable on limited evaluation. MIP/3D: No additional concerning findings. IMPRESSION: Impression: 1. Multiple acute pulmonary emboli involving segmental branches of the pulmonary arteries bilaterally with overall small clot burden on limited evaluation. No obvious right heart strain. 2. New postobstructive consolidation in the anterior aspect of the right upper lobe which is relatively hypodense in attenuation and concerning for developing pulmonary abscess or infarct. Additional differential includes new neoplasm though this is felt to be less likely given short-term interval development. 3. New patchy consolidation in the medial and inferior aspect of the right upper lobe likely secondary to aspiration. 4. Increased moderate right pleural effusion and new small left pleural effusion with associated partial atelectasis of the bilateral lower lobes. 5. Decreased size of mediastinal mass centered in the right upper paratracheal region. Unchanged spiculated nodule in the right middle lobe. 6. Moderate biatrial enlargement with likely associated reflux of contrast into the hepatic veins concerning for right heart dysfunction. 7. Unchanged compression fractures of T10 and T11. Urgent findings were communicated to NP AMANDA ANNE TRAINER by Oliver Edwards, MD on 2/28/2024 11:38 AM via Epic secure messaging system with confirmation of receipt by provider. Report E-Signed By: Oliver L Edwards at 2/28/2024 11:39 AM WSN:RICRAD32
